so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=cl.:6" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Claud. 6</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">si reperire vocas amittere certius,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>to know more certainly that she is lost</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:5:519" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 5, 519</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">colores,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:3:5:27" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 3, 5, 27</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:1:1:60" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> S. 1, 1, 60</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">2, 5, 2</bibl> (not elsewh. in Hor.).</sense></entryFree>
ammi: <entryFree id="n2261" type="greek" key="ammi"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ammi</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">ami</orth>) and <orth extent="full" lang="la">ammium</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">ami-um</orth>), <itype>ii</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)/mmi</foreign> and <foreign lang="greek">a)/mmion</foreign>, <sense id="n2261.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">ammi</hi>, <hi rend="ital">an umbelliferous plant</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">est cumino simillimum quod Graeei vocant ami,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:20:163" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 20, 15, 58, § 163</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:20:264" default="NO" valid="yes">20, 24, 100, § 264</bibl> Jan. (al. <hi rend="ital">ammium</hi>): <cit><quote lang="la">ammium,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1011,001:Comp. 121" default="NO"><author>Scrib.</author> Comp. 121</bibl></cit> <hi rend="ital">ext.</hi></sense></entryFree>
ammianus: <entryFree id="n2262" type="main" key="Ammi^a_nus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ammĭānus Marcellīnus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n2262.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a Latin historian of the 4th century.</hi> Of his work, Rerum gestarum libri XXXI., which extended from the beginning of the reign of Nerva (91 A.D.) to the death of Valens (378), the first thirteen books are lost; cf., concerning him, Bähr. <usg type="style">Lit.</usg> Gesch. 349 sq., and Teuffel, Rom. <usg type="style">Lit.</usg> § 421, 1-5.</sense></entryFree>
ammineus: <entryFree id="n2263" type="main" key="Ammi_ne_us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ammīnēus</orth>, i. q. Aminaeus.</entryFree>
ammiror: <entryFree id="n2264" type="main" key="ammi_ror"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ammīror</orth> and <orth extent="full" lang="la">ammitto</orth>, v. admiror, etc.</entryFree>
ammium: <entryFree id="n2265" type="main" key="ammium"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ammium</orth>, v. ammi.</entryFree>
ammochrysus: <entryFree id="n2266" type="greek" key="ammo^chry_sus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ammŏchrȳsus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)mmo/xrusos</foreign> <pb n="107" /> <cb n="AMNI" /> (gold sand), <sense id="n2266.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a precious stone unknown to us</hi>, perh. golden mica, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:37:188" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 37, 11, 73, § 188</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
ammodytes: <entryFree id="n2267" type="greek" key="ammo^dy^te_s"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ammŏdytēs</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)mmodu/ths</foreign> (sand-burrower), <sense id="n2267.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a kind of serpent in Africa</hi>, * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0917,001:9:716" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Luc.</author> 9, 716</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Sol.</author> 27 al.</bibl></sense></entryFree>
ammon: <entryFree id="n2268" type="main" key="Ammo_n"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ammōn</orth>, better <orth extent="full" lang="la">Hammon</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>Egypt. Amun</etym>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)/ammwn</foreign>, <sense id="n2268.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a name of Jupiler</hi>, <hi rend="ital">worshipped in Africa under the form of a ram</hi> (on the present oasis Siwah). Connected with his temple was an oracle often consulted by the ancients; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0472,001:7:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cat.</author> 7, 5</bibl> sqq.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:4:7" default="NO"><author>Curt.</author> 4, 7</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0917,001:9:511 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Luc.</author> 9, 511 al.</bibl>—Whence Ammonis cornu, <hi rend="ital">a gold-colored precious stone of the shape of a ram's horn</hi>, <hi rend="ital">ammonite</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:37:167" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 37, 10, 60, § 167</bibl>.—Hence, </sense><sense id="n2268.1" n="II" level="1"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Ammōnĭăcus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <hi rend="ital">belonging to Ammon</hi> (<hi rend="ital">Africa</hi>, <hi rend="ital">Libya</hi>): <cit><quote lang="la">sal,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:31:79" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 31, 7, 39, § 79</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:6:17:7" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 6, 17, 7</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,003:94" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> Med. Fac. 94</bibl>.—<orth extent="full" lang="la">Ammō-nĭăcum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen> <hi rend="ital">subst.</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a resinous gum</hi>, <hi rend="ital">which distils from a tree near the temple of Jupiter Ammon</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Ammoniaci lacrima,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:12:107" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 12, 23, 49, § 107</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Ammoniaci lacrimae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:20:197" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 20, 18, 75, § 197</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Ammoniaci guttae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1011,001:Comp. 28:35" default="NO"><author>Scrib.</author> Comp. 28, 35</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0836,001:5:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cels.</author> 5, 5</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
ammoneo: <entryFree id="n2269" type="main" key="ammo^ne^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ammŏnĕo</orth> and <orth extent="full" lang="la">ammŏnī^trix</orth>, v. admoneo, etc.</entryFree>
ammonitrum: <entryFree id="n2270" type="greek" key="ammo^ni_^trum"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ammŏnī^trum</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">ham-</orth>), <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)mmo/nitron</foreign>, <sense id="n2270.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">natron mingled with sand</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:36:194" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 36, 26, 26, § 194</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
amnacum: <entryFree id="n2271" type="main" key="amna^cum"><orth extent="full" lang="la">amnăcum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, <sense id="n2271.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">an herbaceous plant</hi>, <hi rend="ital">pellitory</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:21:176" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 21, 30, 104, § 176</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
amnenses: <entryFree id="n2272" type="gloss" key="amnenses"><orth extent="full" lang="la">amnenses</orth> or <orth extent="full" lang="la">amnēses</orth>, <itype>ium</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>amnis</etym>, <sense id="n2272.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">towns situated near a river</hi>, Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=17" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 17</bibl> Müll.</sense></entryFree>
amnestia: <entryFree id="n2273" type="greek" key="amnesti^a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">amnestĭa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)mnhsti/a</foreign> (a forgetting), <sense id="n2273.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">an amnesty</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a forgiving</hi> or <hi rend="ital">pardoning of a state crime</hi>: haec oblivio, quam Athenienses <foreign lang="greek">a)mnhsti/an</foreign> vocant, <bibl default="NO"><author>Vop.</author> Aur. 39</bibl> (<bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,001:Thras. 3:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Thras. 3, 2</bibl>, uses for it oblivio; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">venia et oblivio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=cl.:11" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Claud. 11</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">abolitio facti,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=tib.:4" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tib. 4</bibl></cit>).</sense></entryFree>
amnicola: <entryFree id="n2274" type="hapax" key="amni^co^la"><orth extent="full" lang="la">amnĭcŏla</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>comm.</gen> <etym>amnis-colo</etym>, <sense id="n2274.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">that dwells upon</hi> or <hi rend="ital">grows by a river</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">salices,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:10:96" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 10, 96</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
amniculus: <entryFree id="n2275" type="hapax" key="amni^cu^lus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">amnĭcŭlus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <lbl>dim.</lbl> <etym>amnis</etym>, <sense id="n2275.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a small river</hi>, <hi rend="ital">rivulet</hi>, <hi rend="ital">brook</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:36:22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 36, 22 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></sense></entryFree>
amnicus: <entryFree id="n2276" type="main" key="amni^cus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">amnĭcus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n2276.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">pertaining to a river</hi> (only post-class.): <cit><quote lang="la">calami,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:16:166" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 16, 36, 66, § 166</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">insula Metubarris amnicarum maxima,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>of those formed by rivers</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:3:148" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 3, 25, 28, § 148</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">calami,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:16:166" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 16, 36, 66, § 166</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pisces,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Sol.</author> 37</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">terga,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Aus.</author> Mos. 205</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
amnigena: <entryFree id="n2277" type="main" key="amni^ge^na"><orth extent="full" lang="la">amnĭgĕna</orth>, <itype>ae</itype> <etym>amnis-gigno</etym>. <sense id="n2277.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Born in a river</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">pisces,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Aus.</author> Mos. 116</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n2277.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Born of a river-god</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Choaspes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1035,001:5:602" default="NO"><author>Val. Fl.</author> 5, 602</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
amnis: <entryFree id="n2278" type="main" key="amnis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">amnis</orth>, <itype>is</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> (<sense id="n2278.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">fem.</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,011:5:2:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Merc. 5, 2, 18</bibl>; Naev. and Att. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 191, 33</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 3:5:9" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 3, 5, 9</bibl>; cf. Prisc. pp. 652 and 658 P.; Rudd. I. p. 26, n. 37; Schne<bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:Gram. 2:98" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Gram. 2, 98</bibl>; <case>abl.</case> regularly amne; <cit><quote lang="la">but freq. amni in the poets,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:1:203" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 1, 203</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">3, 447</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:1:10:62" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 1, 10, 62</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:R. R. 10:136" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> R. R. 10, 136</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">also in prose,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:21:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 21, 5</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:21:27 al" default="NO" valid="yes">21, 27 al.</bibl>; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>Prisc.</author> p. 766</bibl>; Rhem. Pal. 1374 P.; Rudd. I. p. 85, n. 85) [qs. for apnis from Sanscr. ap = water; <gen>n.</gen> <number>plur.</number> āpas. Van.; v. aqua], orig., <hi rend="ital">any broad and deep-flowing</hi>, <hi rend="ital">rapid water; a stream</hi>, <hi rend="ital">torrent</hi>, <hi rend="ital">river</hi> (hence, esp. in the poets, sometimes for <hi rend="ital">a rapidly-flowing stream</hi> or <hi rend="ital">a torrent rushing down from a mountain</hi> = torrens; sometimes for <hi rend="ital">a large river</hi>, opp. fluvius (a common river); sometimes also for <hi rend="ital">the ocean</hi> as flowing round the land; it most nearly corresponds with our <hi rend="ital">stream;</hi> in prose not often used before the histt. of the Aug. per.; in Cic. only in Aratus and in his more elevated prose; never in his Epistt.). </sense><sense id="n2278.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: acervos altā in amni, Att., Trag. Rel. p. 178 Rib.: apud abundantem antiquam amnem et rapidas undas Inachi, Att. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 192, 4</bibl> (Trag. Rel. p. 175 Rib.): <cit><quote lang="la">Sic quasi amnis celeris rapit, sed tamen inflexu flectitur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0112,001:Trag. Rel. p. 12" default="NO"><author>Naev.</author> Trag. Rel. p. 12</bibl></cit> Rib.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,015:3:3:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Poen. 3, 3, 15</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">molibus incurrit validis cum viribus amnis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:1:288" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 1, 288</bibl></cit> (v. the whole magnificent description, 1, 282- 290): <cit><quote lang="la">Nilus unicus in terris, Aegypti totius amnis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:6:714" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 6, 714</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ruunt de montibus amnes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:4:164" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 4, 164</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">amnes magnitudinis vastae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Q. N. 3:19" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Q. N. 3, 19</bibl></cit>.—Also in distinction from the sea: <cit><quote lang="la">cum pontus et amnes cuncti invicem commeant,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Q. N. 4:2" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Q. N. 4, 2</bibl></cit>.—On the contr. of the <hi rend="ital">ocean</hi>, acc. to the Gr. <foreign lang="greek">*)wkeano\s potamo/s</foreign> (Hom. Od. 11, 639): <cit><quote lang="la">Oceani amnis,</quote> <trans><tr>the ocean-stream</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:4:233" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 4, 233</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quā fluitantibus undis Solis anhelantes abluit amnis equos,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0660,001:2:5:60" default="NO"><author>Tib.</author> 2, 5, 60</bibl></cit>: Nox Mundum caeruleo<cb n="AMO" />  laverat amne rotas, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0660,001:3:4:18 al" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 3, 4, 18 al.</bibl>—</sense><sense id="n2278.2" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg> </sense><sense id="n2278.3" n="A" level="2"> <usg type="style">Poet.</usg>, of the constellation Eridanus: <cit><quote lang="la">Eridanum cernes funestum magnis cum viribus amnem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,060:chapter=145" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Arat. 145</bibl></cit> (as a transl. of the Gr. <foreign lang="greek">lei/yanon *)hridanoi=o, poluklau/stou potamoi=o</foreign>, Arat. Phaenom. 360): Scorpios exoriens cum clarus fugerit amnis, Germanic. Arat. 648; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 362</bibl>. —</sense><sense id="n2278.4" n="B" level="2"> Also <usg type="style">poet.</usg> and in post-class. prose, <hi rend="ital">any thing flowing</hi>, <hi rend="ital">liquid</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:12:417" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 12, 417</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">7, 465</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">amnis musti,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Pall.</author> 11, 14, 18</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n2278.5" n="C" level="2"> Of a writer, whose eloquence is thus compared to a flowing stream (v. flumen, II. B. and fluo, II. 2. B. 1.): alter (Herodotus) sine ullis salebris quasi sedatus amnis (i. e. <hi rend="ital">a noiseless stream flowing on in majestic size and fulness</hi>) fluit; <cit><quote lang="la">alter (Thucydides) incitatior fertur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,040:12:39" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Or. 12, 39</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n2278.6" n="D" level="2"> Like flumen, as abstr., <hi rend="ital">a current</hi>, <hi rend="ital">stream</hi>: secundo amni, <hi rend="ital">down</hi> or <hi rend="ital">with the stream</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:3:447" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 3, 447</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">adverso amne,</quote> <trans><tr>up the stream</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:10:1 al" default="NO"><author>Curt.</author> 10, 1 al.</bibl></cit></sense></entryFree>
amnon: <entryFree id="n2279" type="main" key="Amnon"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Amnon</orth>, <sense id="n2279.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a river in Arabia Felix</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:6:151" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 6, 28, 32, § 151</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
amo: <entryFree id="n2280" type="main" key="a^mo"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ămo</orth>, <itype>āvi, ātum, 1</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos> (amāsso = amavero, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,006:5:4:23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Cas. 5, 4, 23</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,008:4:4:22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Curc. 4, 4, 22</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,012:4:2:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Mil. 4, 2, 16</bibl>; cf. Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=28" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 28</bibl> Müll.: <sense id="n2280.0" n="I" level="1"><cit><quote lang="la">amāsse = amavisse,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,003:5:1:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Eun. 5, 1, 11</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">amantum = amantium,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,010:2:3:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Men. 2, 3, 4</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:4:1077" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 4, 1077</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,004:1:439" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> A. A. 1, 439</bibl>) [cf. Sanscr. kam = to love; <foreign lang="greek">a(/ma</foreign> = Sanscr. sam = Germ. sammt; Engl. same, Lat. similis; with the radical notion of likeness, union], <hi rend="ital">to like</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to love</hi>, <foreign lang="greek">e)ra/w, file/w</foreign> (both in the higher and the lower sense, opp. odisse; while <hi rend="ital">diligere</hi> (<foreign lang="greek">a)gapw=</foreign>) designates esteem, regard; opp. neglegere or spernere; cf. Doed. Syn. IV. p. 97; in the high sense in the philos. writings and Epp. of Cicero; often in the low sense, esp. in the comic poets. In the Vulg. amo and amor are comparatively little used, prob. from their bad associations, amo being used 51 times and amor 20. Instead of these words, diligo, dilectio and caritas were used. Diligo (incl. dilectus) occurs 422 times, and dilectio and caritas 144 times in all; dilectio 43 and caritas 101 times). </sense><sense id="n2280.1" n="I" level="1"> In gen.: <cit><quote lang="la">quid autem est amare, nisi velle bonis aliquem adfici, quam maximis, etiamsi ad se ex iis nihil redeat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:2:24" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fin. 2, 24</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">amare autem nihil aliud est, nisi eum ipsum diligere, quem ames, nullā indigentiā, nullā utilitate quaesitā,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,052:27:100" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Am. 27, 100</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">videas corde amare (eos) inter se,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,005:2:3:60" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Capt. 2, 3, 60</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,006:5:3:42" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Ad. 5, 3, 42</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">liberi amare patrem atque matrem videntur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:12:1:23" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 12, 1, 23</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">qui amat patrem aut matrem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,001:6:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Matt. 6, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ipse Pater amat vos, h. l. used of God,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,004:16:27" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Joan. 16, 27</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Cicerones pueri amant inter se,</quote> <trans><tr>love each other</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:6:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 6, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">magis te quam oculos nunc amo meos,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,006:4:5:67" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Ad. 4, 5, 67</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quem omnes amare meritissimo debemus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:1:55:234" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 1, 55, 234</bibl></cit>.—So, amare aliquem ex animo, <hi rend="ital">to love with all one's heart</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,058:1:1:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Q. Fr. 1, 1, 5</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">unice patriam et cives,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,013:3:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Cat. 3, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aliquem amore singulari,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:15:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 15, 20</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">sicut mater unicum amat filium suum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,012:1:26" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> 2 Reg. 1, 26</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">dignus amari,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,001:5:89" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> E. 5, 89</bibl></cit>.—Amare in ccntr. with diligere, as stronger, more affectionate: Clodius valde me diligit, vel, ut <foreign lang="greek">e)mfatikw/teron</foreign> dicam, valde me amat, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,059:1:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> ad Brut. 1, 1</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:9:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 9, 14</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">eum a me non diligi solum, verum etiam amari,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 13, 47</bibl></cit>; id. Fragm. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 421, 30</bibl> (Orell. IV. 2, p. 466); <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1318,001:3:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> Ep. 3, 9</bibl>.—But diligere, as indicative of esteem, is more emph. than amare, which denotes an instinctive or affectionate love: <cit><quote lang="la">non quo quemquam plus amem, aut plus diligam, Eo feci, sed, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,003:1:2:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Eun. 1, 2, 16</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">homo nobilis, qui a suis et amari et diligi vellet,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:4:23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 4, 23</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">te semper amavi dilexique,</quote> <trans><tr>have loved and esteemed</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:15:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 15, 7</bibl></cit>: diligis (<foreign lang="greek">a)gapa=|s</foreign>) me plus his? Etiam, Domine, tu scis quia amo (<foreign lang="greek">filw=</foreign>) te, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,004:21:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Joan. 21, 15</bibl> sqq., ubi v. Alford, Gr. Test. al.—Hence in asseverations: ita (sic) me dii (bene) ament <hi rend="ital">or</hi> amabunt, <hi rend="ital">so may the gods love me</hi>, <hi rend="ital">by the love of the gods</hi>, <hi rend="ital">most assuredly</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ita me di amabunt, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,015:1:3:30" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Poen. 1, 3, 30</bibl></cit> (v. the pass. in its connection): <cit><quote lang="la">ita me di ament, credo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:5:4:44" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> And. 5, 4, 44</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">non, ita me di bene ament,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,005:2:1:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Hec. 2, 1, 9</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">sic me di amabunt, ut, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:3:1:54" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Heaut. 3, 1, 54</bibl></cit>.—Hence also ellipt.: ita me Juppiter! (sc. amet <hi rend="ital">or</hi> amabit), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,015:1:3:31" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Poen. 1, 3, 31</bibl> (so in Engl. with different ellipsis, <hi rend="ital">bless me!</hi> sc. <hi rend="ital">God</hi>).—And as a salutation: <hi rend="ital">Me.</hi> Salvus atque fortunatus, <cb n="AMO" /> Euclio, semper sies. <hi rend="ital">Eu.</hi> Di te ament, Me gadore, <hi rend="ital">the gods bless you!</hi> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,003:2:2:6 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Aul. 2, 2, 6 al.</bibl>—</sense><sense id="n2280.2" n="II" level="1"> Esp. </sense><sense id="n2280.3" n="A" level="2"> Amare se, of vain men, <hi rend="ital">to be in love with</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to be pleased with one's self</hi>, also, <hi rend="ital">to be selfish</hi> (used mostly by Cic.): <cit><quote lang="la">quam se ipse amans sine rivali!</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,058:3:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Q. Fr. 3, 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nisi nosmet ipsos valde amabimus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:1:9:29" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Off. 1, 9, 29</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:4:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 4, 16 <hi rend="ital">med.</hi></bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,021:chapter=9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Har. Resp. 9</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">homines se ipsos amantes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,015:3:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> 2 Tim. 3, 2</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n2280.4" n="B" level="2"> Of unlawful love, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,004:2:2:30" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Bacch. 2, 2, 30</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut videas eam medullitus me amare!</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,013:1:3:86" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Most. 1, 3, 86</bibl></cit> et saep.: <cit><quote lang="la">meum gnatum rumor est amare,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:1:2:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> And. 1, 2, 14</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">1, 2, 20 al.</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ibi primum insuevit exercitus populi Romani amare, potare, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:C. 11:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> C. 11, 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quae (via) eo me solvat amantem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:4:479" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 4, 479</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">non aequo foedere amare,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 4, 520</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:2:3:250" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 2, 3, 250</bibl> Heind.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,026:16:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Jud. 16, 4</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,012:13:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> 2 Reg. 13, 4</bibl> al. —</sense><sense id="n2280.5" n="C" level="2"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">to love</hi> a thing, <hi rend="ital">to like</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to be fond of</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to find pleasure in</hi>, <hi rend="ital">delight in</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">nomen, orationem, vultum, incessum alicujus amare,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,022:49:105" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Sest. 49, 105</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">amavi amorem tuum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:9:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 9, 16</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Alexidis manum amabam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:7:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 7, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">amabat litteras,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,025:1:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Att. 1, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ea, quae res secundae amant, lasciviā atque superbiā incessere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 41:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 41, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">amare nemus et fugere urbem,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 2, 2, 77</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">amat bonus otia Daphnis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,001:5:61" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> E. 5, 61</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">non omnes eadem mirantur amantque,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 2, 2, 58</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">mirā diversitate naturā, cum īdem homines sic ament inertiam et oderint quietem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,002:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> G. 15</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pax et quies tunc tantum amata,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 40</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">qui amant vinum et pinguia,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,029:21:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Prov. 21, 17</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">amant salutationes in foro,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,003:20:46" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Luc. 20, 46</bibl></cit>: amat Janua limen, <hi rend="ital">loves to remain shut</hi>, i. e. <hi rend="ital">is constantly closed</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:1:25:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 1, 25, 3</bibl>; so, <cit><quote lang="la">Nilus amet alveum suum,</quote> <trans><tr>keep to its bed</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1318,002:31:4 al" default="NO"><author>Plin.</author> Pan. 31, 4 al.</bibl></cit>—With <hi rend="ital">inf.</hi> as object: <cit><quote lang="la">hic ames dici pater atque princeps,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:1:2:50" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 1, 2, 50</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">amant in synagogis orare,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,001:6:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Matt. 6, 5</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n2280.6" n="D" level="2"> Amare aliquem de <hi rend="ital">or</hi> in aliquā re, quod, etc., <hi rend="ital">to like one for something</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to be obliged to one for something</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to be under obligation</hi>, <hi rend="ital">be thankful.</hi> </sense><sense id="n2280.7" n="a" level="4"> With <hi rend="ital">de</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ecquid nos amas De fidicinā istac?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,003:3:2:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Eun. 3, 2, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">de raudusculo multum te amo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:7:2:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 7, 2, 7</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n2280.8" n="b" level="4"> With <hi rend="ital">in</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">et in Attilii negotio te amavi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:13:62" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 13, 62</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n2280.9" n="c" level="4"> With <hi rend="ital">quod</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">te multum amamus, quod, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:1:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 1, 3</bibl></cit>: amas me, quod te non vidi? Domit. Afer. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:6:3:93" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 6, 3, 93</bibl>.—Also without <pos>prep.</pos> or <hi rend="ital">quod</hi>: soror, parce, amabo. <hi rend="ital">Anter.</hi> Quiesco. <hi rend="ital">Adelph.</hi> Ergo amo te, <hi rend="ital">I like you</hi>, <hi rend="ital">am much obliged to you</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,015:1:2:40" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Poen. 1, 2, 40</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">bene facis: Merito te amo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,006:5:8:23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Ad. 5, 8, 23</bibl></cit>.—Hence in the eilipt. lang. of conversation, amabo <hi rend="ital">or</hi> amabo te (never amabo vos, etc.), lit. <hi rend="ital">I shall like you</hi> (<hi rend="ital">if you say</hi>, <hi rend="ital">do</hi>, etc., <hi rend="ital">that for me</hi>).—Hence in entreaties = oro, quaeso, precor (with <hi rend="ital">ut</hi> or <hi rend="ital">ne</hi> foll.), <hi rend="ital">be so good</hi>, <hi rend="ital">I pray</hi>, <hi rend="ital">entreat you</hi> (in Plaut. and Ter. very freq.; in the latter always amabo without te; <cit><quote lang="la">in Cic. only in Epistt.): quis hic, amabo, est, qui, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,012:3:3:26" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Mil. 3, 3, 26</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">qui, amabo?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,004:1:1:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Bacch. 1, 1, 19</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quid, amabo, obticuisti?</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 1, 28</bibl></cit> et saep.: <cit><quote lang="la">id, amabo, adjuta me,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,003:1:2:70" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Eun. 1, 2, 70</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">id agite, amabo,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 2, 50</bibl></cit> al.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0472,001:32:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cat.</author> 32, 1</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">id, amabo te, huic caveas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,004:1:1:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Bacch. 1, 1, 10</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,010:4:3:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Men. 4, 3, 4</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">amabo te, advola,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,058:2:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Q. Fr. 2, 10</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cura, amabo te, Ciceronem nostrum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:2:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 2, 2</bibl></cit>.—With <hi rend="ital">ut</hi> or <hi rend="ital">ne</hi> foll.: <cit><quote lang="la">scin quid te amabo ut facias?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,010:2:3:71" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Men. 2, 3, 71</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">3, 3, 1</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">amabo, ut illuc transeas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,003:3:3:31" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Eun. 3, 3, 31</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">amabo te, ne improbitati meae assignes, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,058:1:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Q. Fr. 1, 4</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n2280.10" n="E" level="2"> With <hi rend="ital">inf.</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to do a thing willingly</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to be wont</hi> or <hi rend="ital">accustomed to</hi> (cf. <foreign lang="greek">file/w</foreign>; mostly <usg type="style">poet.</usg> or in post-Aug. prose): <cit><quote lang="la">clamore, vultu, saepe impetu, atque aliis omnibus, quae ira fieri amat,</quote> <trans><tr>delights to have done</tr>, <tr>is wont to do</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 34:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 34, 1</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:9:3:17" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 9, 3, 17</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">aurum per medios ire satellites Et perrumpere amat saxa potentius Ictu fulmineo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:3:16:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 3, 16, 9</bibl></cit>; so <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 3, 9</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,003:8:15" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Epod. 8, 15</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:13:28" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 13, 4, 7, § 28</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:4:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 4, 9</bibl>.—Hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">ămans</orth>, <itype>antis</itype>, <pos>P. a.</pos>, with <hi rend="ital">gen.</hi> or <hi rend="ital">absol.</hi> </sense><sense id="n2280.11" n="A" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">Fond</hi>, <hi rend="ital">loving</hi>, <hi rend="ital">kind</hi>, <hi rend="ital">feeling kindly to</hi>, <hi rend="ital">benevolent</hi>, <hi rend="ital">pleasing;</hi> and subst., <hi rend="ital">a friend</hi>, <hi rend="ital">patron</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">continentem, amantem uxoris maxime,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,002:5:2:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> As. 5, 2, 7</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">veterem amicum suum studiosum, amantem, observantem sui,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,030:chapter=16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Rab. Post. 16</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">homines amantes tui,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:9:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 9, 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cives amantes patriae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:9:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 9, 19</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,058:1:1:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Q. Fr. 1, 1, 5</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">amans cruoris,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,009:2:9:46" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> P. 2, 9, 46</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad nos amantissimos tui veni,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:16:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 16, 7</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Amantissimus Domini habitabit in eo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,005:33:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Deut. 33, 12</bibl></cit>; ib. Amos, 5, 11: amantissima eorum non proderunt iis, <hi rend="ital">their most</hi> <pb n="108" /> <cb n="AMOE" /> <hi rend="ital">pleasant things</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,048:44:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Isa. 44, 9</bibl>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,036:9:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Os. 9, 16</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n2280.12" n="B" level="2"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>, of things, <hi rend="ital">friendly</hi>, <hi rend="ital">affectionate</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">nomen amantius indulgentiusque,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,010:chapter=5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Clu. 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">lenissimis et amantissimis verbis utens,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:5:15 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 5, 15 al.</bibl></cit>—</sense><sense id="n2280.13" n="C" level="2"> Sometimes in a bad sense = amator or amica, <hi rend="ital">a paramour;</hi> cf. Wolf ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:4:12:27" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 4, 12, 27</bibl>; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 1, 1, 38</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">quis fallere possit amantem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:4:296" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 4, 296</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">4, 429</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">amantium irae amoris integratio est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:3:3:23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> And. 3, 3, 23</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">oblitos famae melioris amantīs,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:4:221" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 4, 221</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">perjuria amantūm,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,004:1:633" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> A. A. 1, 633</bibl></cit>.— Hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">ămanter</orth>, <pos>adv.</pos>, <hi rend="ital">lovingly</hi>, <hi rend="ital">affectionately</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:5:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 5, 19</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:2:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 2, 4</bibl>.—<hi rend="ital">Comp.</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:1:43" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 1, 43</bibl>.—<hi rend="ital">Sup.</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,052:chapter=1" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Am. 1</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
amodo: <entryFree id="n2281" type="main" key="a_mo^do"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ā-mŏdo</orth> (better, separately), <pos>adv.</pos> <etym>formed after the Greek; v. examples</etym>, <sense id="n2281.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">from this time forward</hi>, <hi rend="ital">henceforth</hi>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)po\ tou/tou</foreign> (only in eccl. Lat.): a modo et usque in sempiternum (Gr. <foreign lang="greek">a)po\ tou= nu=n</foreign>), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,048:9:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Isa. 9, 7</bibl>; so <bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> ib. 59, 21</bibl>: non me videbitis a modo, donec etc. (Gr. <foreign lang="greek">a)p) a)rti/</foreign>), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,001:23:39" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Matt. 23, 39</bibl>; so <bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> ib. 26, 29</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,004:13:19 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Joan. 13, 19 al.</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Hier.</author> Vit. Hil. 51, p. 157</bibl> Francf.; <bibl default="NO"><author>Paul. Nol.</author> 8, 28</bibl>; cf. Hand, Turs. I. p. 286.</sense></entryFree>
amoebaeus: <entryFree id="n2282" type="main" key="a^moebaeus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ămoebaeus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)moibai=os</foreign>. <sense id="n2282.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">alternate</hi> (pure Lat. alternus); hence, amoebaeum carmen = <foreign lang="greek">a)=|sma a)moibai=on</foreign>, <hi rend="ital">a responsive song</hi>, Fest.; <bibl default="NO"><author>Serv.</author> ad Verg. E. 3, 28, 59, 66 al.</bibl>—Hence in metre, pes amoebaeus: <cit><quote lang="la">ex duabus longis et totidem brevibus et longā,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Diom.</author> p. 478</bibl></cit> P. (e. g. īncrēdĭbĭlēs; opp. antamoebaeus, q. v.).</sense></entryFree>
amoebeus: <entryFree id="n2283" type="main" key="A^moebeus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ămoebeus</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">trisyl.</orth>), <itype>ĕi</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)amoibeu/s</foreign>, <sense id="n2283.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a distinguished Athenian harp-player</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,004:3:399" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> A. A. 3, 399</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
amoene: <entryFree id="n2284" type="main" key="a^moene_"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ămoenē</orth>, <pos>adv.</pos>, v. amoenus <sense id="n2284.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></sense></entryFree>
amoenitas: <entryFree id="n2285" type="main" key="a^moeni^tas"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ămoenĭtas</orth>, <itype>ātis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>amoenus</etym>, <sense id="n2285.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">pleas antness</hi>, <hi rend="ital">delightfulness</hi>, <hi rend="ital">loveliness.</hi> </sense><sense id="n2285.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>, of places (as scenery, a garden, river, etc.; in the poets, except Plaut., rare; <cit><quote lang="la">never in Ter., Lucr., or Hor.): nunc domus suppeditat mihi hortorum amoenitatem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,058:3:1:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Q. Fr. 3, 1, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">fluminis,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 3, 1, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">amoenitates orarum et litorum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:2:39" default="NO"><author>id.</author> N. D. 2, 39</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,044:2:1" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Leg. 2, 1</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,043:2:4" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Rep. 2, 4</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,025:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Att. 13</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:1:4:8" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 1, 4, 8</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1242,001:2:11:4 al" default="NO"><author>Flor.</author> 2, 11, 4 al.</bibl>—</sense><sense id="n2285.2" n="II" level="1"> Metaph. </sense><sense id="n2285.3" n="A" level="2"> Of other things (so in Plaut. and the prose-writers of the post-Aug. per., but not in Cic.): <cit><quote lang="la">amoenitates omnium venerum atque venustatum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,018:2:1:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Stich. 2, 1, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">hic me amoenitate amoenā amoenus oneravit dies,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,005:4:1:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Capt. 4, 1, 7</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">amoenitates studiorum, Plin. praef.: vitae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:5:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 5, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">verborum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:12:1" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 12, 1 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">orationis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:10:3 al" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 10, 3 al.</bibl></cit> —</sense><sense id="n2285.4" n="B" level="2"> As a term of endearment: <cit><quote lang="la">uxor mea, mea amoenitas, quid tu agis?</quote> <trans><tr>my delight</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,006:2:3:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Cas. 2, 3, 13</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">mea vita, mea amoenitas, meus ocellus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,015:1:2:152" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Poen. 1, 2, 152</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
amoeniter: <entryFree id="n2286" type="main" key="a^moeni^ter"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ămoenĭter</orth>, <pos>adv.</pos>, v. amoenus <sense id="n2286.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></sense></entryFree>
amoeno: <entryFree id="n2287" type="main" key="a^moeno"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ămoeno</orth>, <itype>āre</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos> <etym>amoenus</etym>, late Lat. <sense id="n2287.0" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>, of places, <hi rend="ital">to make pleasant</hi>: regio aut consita pomis aut amoenata lucis, Salv Gub. Dei, 7 <hi rend="ital">med.</hi>—</sense><sense id="n2287.1" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">to please</hi>, <hi rend="ital">delight</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">amoenare oculos,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cypr.</author> Ep. 2, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">amoenare felices animas,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cassiod.</author> Ep. 2, 40 al.</bibl></cit></sense></entryFree>
amoenus: <entryFree id="n2288" type="main" key="a^moenus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ămoenus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>amo; some comp. <foreign lang="greek">a)mei/nwn</foreign></etym>, <sense id="n2288.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">lovely</hi>, <hi rend="ital">delightful</hi>, <hi rend="ital">pleasant</hi>, <hi rend="ital">charming</hi> (in gen. of objects affecting the sense of sight only; as a beautiful landscape, gar dens, rivers, pictures, etc.: amoena loca.. quod solum amorem praestentetad se amanda adliciant, Varr. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Isid.</author> Orig. 14</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">amoena sunt loca solius voluptatis plena,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Serv.</author> ad Verg. A. 5, 734</bibl></cit>; while <hi rend="ital">jucundus</hi> is used both in a phys. and mental sense; cf. Doed. Syn. III. p 36; class. in prose and poetry). </sense><sense id="n2288.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: amoena salicta, Enn. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:1:20:40" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Div. 1, 20, 40</bibl> (Ann. v. 40 Vahl.): Ennius, qui primus amoeno Detulit ex Helicone perenni fronde coronam, <hi rend="ital">who first from the charming Helicon</hi>, etc., <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:1:117" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 1, 117</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">fons,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:4:1024" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 4, 1024</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">locus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:2:71:290" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 2, 71, 290</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">praediola,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:16:3:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 16, 3, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">loca amoena voluptaria,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:C. 11:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> C. 11, 5</bibl></cit> Kritz: <cit><quote lang="la">amoena piorum Concilia,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:5:734" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 5, 734</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Devenere locos laetos et amoena virecta Fortunatorum nemorum sedesque beatas,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 6, 638</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">rus,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 1, 10, 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aquae, aurae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:3:4:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> C. 3, 4, 7</bibl></cit>: hae latebrae dulces, etiam, si credis, amoenae, <hi rend="ital">delightful to me</hi> (subjectively), <hi rend="ital">but also in and of themselves</hi> (objectively) <hi rend="ital">pleasant</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Ep. 1, 16, 15</bibl> Schmid.; cf. <cit><quote lang="la">Doed. Syn. III. p. 35: amoenae Farfarus umbrae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:14:330" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 14, 330</bibl></cit>, where Merkel, <hi rend="ital">opacae</hi> Farfarus <hi rend="ital">undae</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">amoenissima aedificia,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:3:30" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 3, 30</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pictura,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:35:10:37" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 35, 10, 37 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>—In reproach: cultus amoenior, <hi rend="ital">too</hi> <cb n="AMOR" /> <hi rend="ital">showy</hi>, <hi rend="ital">coquetting</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:4:44:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 4, 44, 11</bibl>.—As <hi rend="ital">subst.</hi>, <orth extent="full" lang="la">ămoena</orth>, <itype>ōrum</itype>, <gen>n.</gen> (cf. abditus, etc.), <hi rend="ital">pleasant places</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">per amoena Asiae atque Achaiae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:3:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 3, 7</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">amoena litorum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:3:76" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> H. 3, 76</bibl></cit>. —</sense><sense id="n2288.2" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg> to other things (rare, and for the most part only post-Aug.): <cit><quote lang="la">vita,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:15:55" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 15, 55</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ingenium,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 64</bibl></cit>; so <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 13, 3</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">animus, i. e. amoenitatibus deditus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:Epit. 1" default="NO"><author>Aur. Vict.</author> Epit. 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">amoenissima verba,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:2:26" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 2, 26</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:16:3" default="NO">16, 3</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:18:5 al" default="NO">18, 5 al.</bibl>—Hence, <pos>adv.</pos> * </sense><sense id="n2288.3" n="a" level="4"> Old form <orth extent="full" lang="la">ămoenĭter</orth>: <cit><quote lang="la">hilare atque amoeniter vindemiam agitare,</quote> <trans><tr>joyfully and delightfully</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:20:8" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 20, 8</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n2288.4" n="b" level="4"> Usu. form <orth extent="full" lang="la">ămoenē</orth>; <cit><quote lang="la">* in respect to smell,</quote> <trans><tr>sweetly</tr>, <tr>fragrantly</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,012:2:5:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Mil. 2, 5, 2</bibl></cit>; of a dwelling, <hi rend="ital">pleasantly</hi> (in <hi rend="ital">sup.</hi>), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1318,001:4:23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> Ep. 4, 23</bibl>; of discourse (in <hi rend="ital">comp.</hi>), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:14:1:32" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 14, 1, 32</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
amolior: <entryFree id="n2289" type="main" key="a_mo_li^or"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ā-mōlĭor</orth>, <itype>ītus, 4</itype>, <pos>v. dep.</pos>, <sense id="n2289.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to remove</hi> a person or thing <hi rend="ital">from</hi> a place (with effort or difficulty), <hi rend="ital">to move</hi> or <hi rend="ital">carry away</hi>: amoliri dicuntur ea, quae cum magnā difficultate et molimine summoventur et tolluntur e medio, Don. ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:4:2:24" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> And. 4, 2, 24</bibl> (never in Cic. or Hor.). </sense><sense id="n2289.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>, Att. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 75, 31</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">amoliri omnia,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,016:3:2:67" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Ps. 3, 2, 67</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,013:2:1:44" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Most. 2, 1, 44</bibl>: impedimentum omne, Sisenn. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 73, 15</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">omnia e medio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:11:25" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 11, 10, 10, § 25</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">obstantia silvarum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:1:50" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 1, 50</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">onus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0917,001:5:354" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Luc.</author> 5, 354</bibl></cit>.—Hence, amoliri se (ante-class.), <hi rend="ital">to take one's self away</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to go away</hi>: non tu te e conspectu hinc amolire? Pac. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 73, 13</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,020:2:7:68" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Truc. 2, 7, 68</bibl>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,016:1:5:144" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Ps. 1, 5, 144</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">hinc vos amolimini,</quote> <trans><tr>begone</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:4:2:24" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> And. 4, 2, 24</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n2289.2" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">to put away</hi>, <hi rend="ital">avert;</hi> in rhet., <hi rend="ital">to refute</hi>, <hi rend="ital">repel</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">religiosum id gestamen amoliendis periculis arbitrantur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:32:23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 32, 2, 11, § 23</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">invidiam crimenque ab aliquo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:3:75" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 3, 75</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">dedecus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:14:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> A. 14, 14</bibl></cit>: amolior et amoveo nomen meum, i. e. omitto, <hi rend="ital">I pass over</hi>, <hi rend="ital">lay no stress on</hi>, Liv 28, 28: <cit><quote lang="la">videndum etiam, simul nobis plura aggredienda sint, an amolienda singula, i. e. refutanda,</quote> <trans><tr>to be refuted</tr>, <tr>rebutted</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:5:13:11" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 5, 13, 11</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:4:1:29" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 4, 1, 29</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:4:2:27 al" default="NO">4, 2, 27 al.</bibl>!*? <hi rend="ital">Pass.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Jube haec hinc omnia amolirier,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,013:2:1:24" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Most. 2, 1, 24</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum amolita objecta onera armatis dedissent viam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:25:36" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 25, 36</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
amolitio: <entryFree id="n2290" type="hapax" key="a_mo_li_ti^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">āmōlītĭo</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>amolior</etym>, <sense id="n2290.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a removing</hi>, <hi rend="ital">putting away</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ubi infantis aliorsum dati facta ex oculis amolitiost,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:12:1:22" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 12, 1, 22</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
amolitus: <entryFree id="n2291" type="main" key="a_mo_li_tus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">āmōlītus</orth>, <mood>Part.</mood>, of amolior.</entryFree>
amomis: <entryFree id="n2292" type="greek" key="a^mo_mis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ămōmis</orth>, <itype>ĭdis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)mwmi/s</foreign>, <sense id="n2292.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a plant similar to the genuine amomum</hi>, <hi rend="ital">but inferior in fragrance</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:12:49" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 12, 13, 28, § 49</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
amomum: <entryFree id="n2293" type="greek" key="a^mo_mum"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ămōmum</orth> or <orth extent="full" lang="la">-on</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)/mwmon</foreign>, <sense id="n2293.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">an aromatic shrub</hi>, <hi rend="ital">from which the Romans prepared a costly</hi>, <hi rend="ital">fragrant balsam</hi>: Cissus vitiginea, Linn.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:12:43" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 12, 13, 28, § 43</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:16:135" default="NO" valid="yes">16, 32, 59, § 135</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Assyrium vulgo nascetur amomum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,001:4:25" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> E. 4, 25</bibl></cit>; so <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 3, 89</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> P 1, 9, 52</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:5:65" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 5, 65</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0969,001:3:104" default="NO"><author>Pers.</author> 3, 104</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
amor: <entryFree id="n2294" type="main" key="a^mor"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ămor</orth> (old form <orth extent="full" lang="la">ămŏs</orth>, <itype>like honos, labos, colos</itype>, etc., <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,008:1:2:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Curc. 1, 2, 2</bibl>; v. Neue, Formenl. I. p. 170), <itype>ōris</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>amo</etym>, <sense id="n2294.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">love</hi> (to friends, parents, etc.; and also in a low sense; hence in gen., like amo, while <hi rend="ital">caritas</hi>, like diligere, is esteem, regard, etc.; hence amor is used also of brutes, but caritas only of men; v amo <hi rend="ital">init.</hi>): <cit><quote lang="la">Amicitiae caritate et amore cernuntur. Nam cum deorum, tum parentum, patriaeque cultus, eorumque hominum, qui aut sapientiā aut opibus excellunt, ad caritatem referri solet. Conjuges autem et liberi et fratres et alii, quos usus familiaritasque conjunxit, quamquam etiam caritate ipsā, tamen amore maxime continentur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,038:25:88" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Part. Or. 25, 88</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 16, 56</bibl>; Doed. Syn. IV. p. 100 (but <hi rend="ital">amor</hi> is related to <hi rend="ital">benevolentia</hi> as the cause to the effect, since benevolentia designates only an external, friendly treatment; but amor <hi rend="ital">a real</hi>, <hi rend="ital">internal love</hi>): <cit><quote lang="la">amor, ex quo amicitia nominata, princeps est ad benevolentiam conjungendam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,052:8:26" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Am. 8, 26</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nihil enim est, quod studio et benevolentiā, vel amore potius effici non possit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:3:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 3, 9</bibl></cit>; cf. Doed. Syn. IV. p. 105 (very freq. in all periods, and in every kind of style; in a low sense most freq. in the com. and eleg. poets, Petron., and similar authors; v. amo <hi rend="ital">init.</hi>); constr. with <hi rend="ital">in</hi>, <hi rend="ital">erga</hi>, or the <hi rend="ital">obj. gen.</hi> (with the <hi rend="ital">gen.</hi> of the gerund, never in Cic., and perh. in no prose writer; but it is so found in Lucr., Ovid, and Hor.). </sense><sense id="n2294.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: ab his initiis noster in te amor profectus, <cb n="AMOR" /> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:13:29" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 13, 29</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">si quid in te residet amoris erga me,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 5, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">amori nostro (i. e. quo a te amamur) plusculum etiam, quam concedit veritas, largiare,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 5, 12</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">Postquam primus amor deceptam morte fefellit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:4:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 4, 17</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">amabilis super amorem mulierum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,012:1:26" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> 2 Reg. 1, 26</bibl></cit>: in paternitatis amore, <hi rend="ital">brotherly love</hi> (Gr. <foreign lang="greek">filadelfi/a</foreign>), <bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 1</bibl> Pet. 1, 22; <bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 2</bibl> Pet. 1, 7 <hi rend="ital">bis</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">amplecti aliquem amore,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:7:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 7, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">habere amorem erga aliquem,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 9, 14</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">respondere amori amore,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 15, 21</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">conciliare amorem alicui,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:2:51" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> de Or. 2, 51</bibl></cit> et saep.—Of sexual love, whether lawful or unlawful: Medea amore saevo saucia, Enn. Med. ap. Auct. ad <bibl default="NO"><author>Her.</author> 2, 22</bibl> (as a transl. of the Gr. <foreign lang="greek">e)/rwti qumo\n e)kplagei=s) *)ia/sonos</foreign>, Eur. Med. prol. 8): <cit><quote lang="la">videbantur illi (septem anni) pauci dies prae amoris magnitudine,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,001:29:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Gen. 29, 20</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">29, 30</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">is amore projecticiam illam deperit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,007:1:3:43" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Cist. 1, 3, 43</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">amore perdita est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,012:4:6:38" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Mil. 4, 6, 38</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in amore haec omnia sunt vitia,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,003:1:1:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Eun. 1, 1, 14</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aeterno devictus volnere amoris,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:1:35" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 1, 35</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">qui vitat amorem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:4:1069" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 4, 1069</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Nec te noster amor tenet?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:4:307" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 4, 307</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">4, 395</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:4:256" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 4, 256</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ne sit ancillae tibi amor pudori,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:2:4:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 2, 4, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">meretricis amore Sollicitus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:2:3:252" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> S. 2, 3, 252</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut majus esset odium amore, quo ante dilexerat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,012:13:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> 2 Reg. 13, 15</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ambo vulnerati amore ejus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,056:13:10 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Dan. 13, 10 al.</bibl></cit>—In both significations also in the <number>plur.</number>: <cit><quote lang="la">amores hominum in te,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:5:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 5, 10</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">amores sancti,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:3:20:68" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Fin. 3, 20, 68</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:4:34:72" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tusc. 4, 34, 72</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Ille meos, primus qui me sibi junxit, amores Abstulit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:4:28" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 4, 28</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">est is mihi in amoribus, i. e. valde a me amatur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:7:32" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 7, 32</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">meos amores eloquar,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,011:1:1:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Merc. 1, 1, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">meretricii amores,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:5:4:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> And. 5, 4, 10</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quem amore venerio dilexerat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,004:4:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Paus. 4, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">amores et hae deliciae, quae vocantur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,024:chapter=19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Cael. 19</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quando Dido tantos rumpi non speret amores,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:4:292" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 4, 292</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Tabuit ex illo dementer amoribus usa,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:4:259" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 4, 259</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">insanos fateamur amores,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,010:9:519" default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 9, 519</bibl></cit> et saep.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:3:21:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 3, 21, 3</bibl> et saep.— </sense><sense id="n2294.2" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Meton.</usg> </sense><sense id="n2294.3" n="A" level="2"> For <hi rend="ital">the beloved object itself</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">amores et deliciae tuae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:1:36" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Div. 1, 36</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">Pompeius, nostri amores,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:2:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 2, 19</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">16, 6</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">and ironic.: sed redeo ad amores deliciasque nostras, L. Antonium,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:6:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Phil. 6, 5</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,015:1:1:79" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Poen. 1, 1, 79</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:1:617" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 1, 617</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">4, 137 al.</bibl>—</sense><sense id="n2294.4" n="B" level="2"> Personified: Amor, <hi rend="ital">the god of love</hi>, <hi rend="ital">Love</hi>, <hi rend="ital">Cupid</hi>, <foreign lang="greek">*)/erws</foreign>: <cit><quote lang="la">O praeclaram emendatricem vitae poëticam, quae Amorem flagitii et levitatis auctorem in concilio deorum collocandum putet,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:4:32:69" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 4, 32, 69</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Deum esse Amorem turpis et vitio favens finxit libido,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Phaedr. 195" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Phaedr. 195</bibl></cit>: Illum conjugem, quem Amor dederat, qui plus pollet potiorque est patre, vet. poët. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:4:32:69" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 4, 32, 69</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Omnia vincit Amor, et nos cedamus Amori,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,001:10:69" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> E. 10, 69</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Improbe Amor, quid non mortalia corpora cogis?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:4:412" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> A. 4, 412</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Paret Amor dictis carae genetricis,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 689</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Amor non talia curat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,001:10:28" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> E. 10, 28</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nec quid Amor curat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:1:480" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 1, 480</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Amori dare ludum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:3:12:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 3, 12, 1</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:1:2:8" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 1, 2, 8</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">non tot sagittis, Spicula quot nostro pectore fixit Amor,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:3:4:2" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 3, 4, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pharetratus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,008:5:1:22" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> Tr. 5, 1, 22</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Notaque purpureus tela resumit Amor,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,001:2:9:34" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Am. 2, 9, 34</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">movit Amor gemmatas aureus alas,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> R. Am. 39</bibl></cit> et saep.—Also in the <number>plur.</number>, <hi rend="ital">Cupids</hi>, <hi rend="ital">Loves</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">corpora nudorum Amorum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:10:516" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 10, 516</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">lascivi Amores,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:2:11:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 2, 11, 7</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">parvi Amores,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:3:1:11" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 3, 1, 11</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Amores volucres,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> Ep. 16, 201</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pharetrati,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> R. Am. 519 al.</bibl></cit>—</sense><sense id="n2294.5" n="C" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">A strong</hi>, <hi rend="ital">passionate longing for something</hi>, <hi rend="ital">desire</hi>, <hi rend="ital">lust</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">consulatūs amor,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,015:26:73" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Sull. 26, 73</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">gloriae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,016:11:28" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Arch. 11, 28</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">amicitiae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:4:33:70" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tusc. 4, 33, 70</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">lactis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:3:394" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 3, 394</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">vini,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:9:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 9, 18</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">auri,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:1:349" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 1, 349</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">argenti,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:2:3:78" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 2, 3, 78</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nummi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:14:138" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 14, 138</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">laudum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:9:197" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 9, 197</bibl></cit> et saep.: <cit><quote lang="la">cognitionis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:4:7:18" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fin. 4, 7, 18</bibl></cit>.—With <hi rend="ital">gerund</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">edundi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:4:870" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 4, 870</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">habendi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:1:131" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 1, 131</bibl></cit>, and <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 1, 7, 85</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">scribendi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:2:1:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> S. 2, 1, 10</bibl></cit>.—<usg type="style">Poet.</usg>, with <hi rend="ital">inf.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">si tantus amor casus cognoscere nostros,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:2:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 2, 10</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">seu rore pudico Castaliae flavos amor est tibi mergere crines,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,001:1:698" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> Th. 1, 698</bibl></cit>.—* </sense><sense id="n2294.6" n="D" level="2"> <usg type="style">Poet.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">a love-charm</hi>, <hi rend="ital">philtre</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">quaeritur et nascentis equi de fronte revolsus Et matri praereptus amor,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:4:516" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 4, 516</bibl></cit>; upon which passage Serv. remarks: Secundum Plinium, qui dicit in Naturali Historiā (8, 42, 66, § 163 sqq.) pullos equinos habere in fronte quandam carnem, quam eis statim natis adimit mater; quam si quis forte <pb n="109" /> <cb n="AMPE" /> praeripuerit, odit pullum et lac ei denegat; v. hippomanes.</sense></entryFree>
amorabundus: <entryFree id="n2295" type="hapax" key="a^mo_ra_bundus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ămōrābundus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>amor</etym>, <sense id="n2295.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">loving</hi>, <hi rend="ital">amorous</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Laberius in Lacu Averno mulierem amantem verbo inusitatius ficto amorabundam dixit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:11:15:1" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 11, 15, 1</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
amorgus: <entryFree id="n2296" type="main" key="A^morgus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ămorgus</orth> or <orth extent="full" lang="la">-ŏs</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)amorgo/s</foreign>, <sense id="n2296.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">one of the Sporades in the Ægean Sea</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the birthplace of the poet Simonides;</hi> under the Roman emperors, a place for the banishment of criminals; now <hi rend="ital">Amorgo</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:4:70" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 4, 12, 23, § 70</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:4:30" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 4, 30</bibl>; v. Mann. Gr. 734 sq.</sense></entryFree>
amorifer: <entryFree id="n2297" type="hapax" key="a^mo_ri^fer"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ămōrĭfer</orth>, <itype>ĕra, ĕrum</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>amor-fero</etym>, <sense id="n2297.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">producing</hi>, or <hi rend="ital">awakening love</hi>: sagittae, Ven. 6, 2, 13.</sense></entryFree>
amorificus: <entryFree id="n2298" type="hapax" key="a^mo_ri^fi^cus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ămōrĭfĭcus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>amor-facio</etym>, <sense id="n2298.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">causing love</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> Herb. 123</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
amos: <entryFree id="n2299" type="main" key="a^mo^s"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ămŏs</orth>, v. amor.</entryFree>
amosio: <entryFree id="n2300" type="main" key="amosio"><orth extent="full" lang="la">amosio</orth>: annuo, Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=26" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 26</bibl> Müll. (very dub.).</entryFree>
