G. 1, 194</bibl>), <sense id="n2382.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the watery part that flows out in pressing olives</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the lees</hi> or <hi rend="ital">dregs of oil</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Cato</author>, R. R. 91</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">101</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">103</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 1:64" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 1, 64</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:12:50:5" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 12, 50, 5</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:15:33" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 15, 8, 8, § 33</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:3:448" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 3, 448</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
amurcarius: <entryFree id="n2383" type="hapax" key="a^murca_ri^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ămurcārĭus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>amurca</etym>, <sense id="n2383.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">pertaining to the lees of oil</hi> (v. amurca): <cit><quote lang="la">dolia,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cato</author>, R. R. 10, 4</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
amusia: <entryFree id="n2384" type="greek" key="a^mu_si^a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ămūsĭa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)mousi/a</foreign>, <sense id="n2384.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">ignorance of music</hi>, Varr. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> p. 171, 30</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
amusos: <entryFree id="n2385" type="greek" key="a^mu_sos"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ămūsos</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)/mousos</foreign>, <sense id="n2385.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">one unskilled in music</hi>, * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1056,001:1:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vitr.</author> 1, 1 <hi rend="ital">med.</hi></bibl></sense></entryFree>
amussis: <entryFree id="n2386" type="main" key="a^mussis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ămussis</orth>, <itype>is</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>etym. unc.; perh. from am- and assis = axis, a plank, i. e. something flat, straight, moved about a surface in adjusting it</etym> (<case>acc.</case> amussim, v. Neue, Formenl. I. p. 198; <case>abl.</case> and <number>plur.</number> not used; only ante- and post-class.), <sense id="n2386.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a rule</hi> or <hi rend="ital">level</hi>, used by carpenters, masons, etc.: amussis: tabula, quā utuntur ad saxa leviganda, Varr. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> p. 9, 17</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Aus.</author> Idyll. 16, 11</bibl>; cf. Sisenn. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Charis.</author> p. 178</bibl> P.; Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=6" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 6</bibl> Müll. —In class. Lat. in the adv. phrases, </sense><sense id="n2386.1" n="I" level="1"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">ad ămussim</orth> (also written as one word, <orth extent="full" lang="la">ad-ămussim</orth> or <orth extent="full" lang="la">ătamussim</orth>), <hi rend="ital">according to a rule</hi> or <hi rend="ital">level</hi>, i. e. <hi rend="ital">accurately</hi>, <hi rend="ital">exactly</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">adamussim non est numerus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 2:1:26" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 2, 1, 26</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">talionem ad amussim aequiparare,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:20:1:34" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 20, 1, 34</bibl></cit> Hertz: <cit><quote lang="la">ut judicium esse factum atamussim diceres,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:1:4:1" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 1, 4, 1</bibl></cit> id.—</sense><sense id="n2386.2" n="II" level="1"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">exămussim</orth>, <hi rend="ital">according to a rule</hi>, <hi rend="ital">exactly</hi>, <hi rend="ital">quite</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Ne ista edepol, si vera haec loquitur, examussimst optuma,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,001:2:2:213" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Am. 2, 2, 213</bibl></cit> (with the forms adamussim and examussim, cf. the Gr. <foreign lang="greek">e)kpodw/n</foreign> and <foreign lang="greek">e)mpodw/n</foreign>).</sense></entryFree>
amussito: <entryFree id="n2387" type="hapax" key="a^mussi^to"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ămussĭto</orth>, <itype>āre</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos> <etym>amussis</etym>, <sense id="n2387.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to make according to rule</hi>, i. e. <hi rend="ital">accurately</hi>, <hi rend="ital">nicely</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">amussitata indoles,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,012:3:1:38" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Mil. 3, 1, 38</bibl></cit> Ritschl.</sense></entryFree>
amussium: <entryFree id="n2388" type="main" key="a^mussi^um"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ămussĭum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n2388.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a horizontal wheel for denoting the direction of the wind</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1056,001:1:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vitr.</author> 1, 6</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
amyclae: <entryFree id="n2389" type="main" key="A^my_clae"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ămȳclae</orth>, <itype>ārum</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)amu/klai</foreign>. <sense id="n2389.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A town in Laconia</hi>, <hi rend="ital">in a beautiful</hi>, <hi rend="ital">fertile region</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the residence of Tyndarus and the birthplace of Castor and Pollux; also renowned on account of its temple and Colossus of Apollo</hi>, now <hi rend="ital">Agios Kyriaki</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:9:104" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 9, 104</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:8:314" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 8, 314</bibl>; cf. Mann. Graec. 616. —</sense><sense id="n2389.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">An unknown town in Latium</hi>, <hi rend="ital">between Cajeta and Tarracina</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:10:564" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 10, 564</bibl>, called tacitae, as being conquered because it was forbidden to announce the approach of an enemy; cf. Serv. ad h. l.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:8:35" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 8, 35</bibl>, and Mann. Ital. 1, 681.—Hence, </sense><sense id="n2389.2" n="III" level="1"> Derivv. </sense><sense id="n2389.3" n="A" level="2"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Ămȳclaeus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <hi rend="ital">of Amyclœ</hi> (<hi rend="ital">in Laconia</hi>): <cit><quote lang="la">canis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:3:345" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 3, 345</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">fratres,</quote> <trans><tr>Castor and Pollux</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,001:7:413" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> Th. 7, 413</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,002:8:71" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> H. 8, 71</bibl>: corona, <hi rend="ital">which were received in pugilistic games</hi>, very freq. in Amyclae, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:9:74" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 9, 74</bibl>.—Poet for <hi rend="ital">Spartan</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:6:504" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 6, 504</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n2389.4" n="B" level="2"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Ămyclānus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <hi rend="ital">belonging to Amyclœ in Latium</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:14:61" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 14, 6, 8, § 61</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
amyclides: <entryFree id="n2390" type="main" key="A^my_cli_de_s"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ămȳclīdēs</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <sense id="n2390.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">patr.</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a male descendant of Amyclas</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the builder of Amyclœ</hi>, i. e. <hi rend="ital">Hyacinthus</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:10:162" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 10, 162</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
amycticus: <entryFree id="n2391" type="greek" key="a^mycti^cus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ămyctĭcus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)muktiko/s</foreign>, <sense id="n2391.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">scratching;</hi> hence, of medical remedies, <hi rend="ital">sharp</hi>, <hi rend="ital">biting</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2305,001:Tard. 2:6" default="NO"><author>Cael. Aur.</author> Tard. 2, 6</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Theod. Prisc.</author> 2, 5</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
amycus: <entryFree id="n2392" type="main" key="A^my^cus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ămycus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)/amukos</foreign>. <sense id="n2392.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Son of Neptune</hi>, <hi rend="ital">king of the Bebrycians</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1035,001:4:148" default="NO"><author>Val. Fl.</author> 4, 148</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n2392.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A centaur slain in the contest with the Lapithœ</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:12:245" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 12, 245</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n2392.2" n="III" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A Trojan</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:10:704" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 10, 704</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
amygdala: <entryFree id="n2393" type="greek" key="a^mygda^la"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ămygdăla</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)mugda/lh</foreign>. <sense id="n2393.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">An almond</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Cato</author>, R. R. 8, 2</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:6:10:12" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 6, 10, 12</bibl>; <pb n="114" /> <cb n="AN" /> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:12:36" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 12, 9, 19, § 36</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n2393.1" n="II" level="1"> = <foreign lang="greek">a)mugdalh=</foreign>, <hi rend="ital">an almond-tree</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:5:10" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 5, 10 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:16:103" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 16, 26, 42, § 103</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
amygdalaceus: <entryFree id="n2394" type="hapax" key="a^mygda^la_ce^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ămygdălācĕus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>amygdala</etym>, <sense id="n2394.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">similar to the almond-tree</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">folium,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:26:111" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 26, 11, 69, § 111</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
amygdaleus: <entryFree id="n2395" type="hapax" key="a^mygda^leus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ămygdăleus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n2395.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">of an almond-tree</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ramus,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Pall.</author> Insit. 157</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
amygdalinus: <entryFree id="n2396" type="main" key="a^mygda^li^nus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ămygdălĭnus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>id.</etym>. <sense id="n2396.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">from almonds</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">oleum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:15:26" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 15, 7, 7, § 26</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n2396.1" n="II" level="1"> Pruna, i. e. <hi rend="ital">ingrafted on an almond-tree</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:15:42" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 15, 13, 12, § 42</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
amygdalites: <entryFree id="n2397" type="hapax" key="a^mygda^li_tes"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ămygdălītes</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n2397.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">like the almond-tree</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:26:70" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 26, 8, 44, § 70</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
amygdalum: <entryFree id="n2398" type="greek" key="a^mygda^lum"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ămygdălum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)mu/gdalon</foreign>, i. q. amygdala. <sense id="n2398.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">An almond</hi>, <hi rend="ital">an almondkernel</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,004:3:183" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> A. A. 3, 183</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Pall.</author> 2, 15 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl>— </sense><sense id="n2398.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">An almond-tree</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:Arb. 25" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> Arb. 25</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
amygdalus: <entryFree id="n2399" type="greek" key="a^mygda^lus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ămygdălus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)mu/gdalos</foreign>, <sense id="n2399.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">an almond-tree</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Pall.</author> 2, 15</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
amylo: <entryFree id="n2400" type="main" key="a^my^lo"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ămylo</orth>, <itype>āre</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos> <etym>amylum</etym>, <sense id="n2400.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to mix with starch</hi> (only post-class.): <cit><quote lang="la">jus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2003,001:7:6" default="NO"><author>Apic.</author> 7, 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">lac,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2305,001:Tard. 2:13" default="NO"><author>Cael. Aur.</author> Tard. 2, 13</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
amylum: <entryFree id="n2401" type="greek" key="a^my^lum"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ămylum</orth> or <orth extent="full" lang="la">ămŭlum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)/mulon</foreign>, <sense id="n2401.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">starch</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Cato</author>, R. R. 87</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0836,001:2:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cels.</author> 2, 20</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:18:76" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 18, 7, 17, § 76</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
amymone: <entryFree id="n2402" type="main" key="A^my_mo_ne_"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ămȳmōnē</orth>, <itype>ēs</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)amumw/nh</foreign>. <sense id="n2402.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Daughter of Danăus</hi>, <hi rend="ital">and grandmother of Palamedes</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0533,001:Fab. 169" default="NO"><author>Hyg.</author> Fab. 169</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:3:22:27" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 3, 22, 27</bibl>. —</sense><sense id="n2402.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A fountain near Argos</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:2:240" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 2, 240</bibl>.—Hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">Ămȳmōnĭus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <hi rend="ital">pertaining to Amymone</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0533,001:Fab. 169" default="NO"><author>Hyg.</author> Fab. 169</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
amyntas: <entryFree id="n2403" type="main" key="A^myntas"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ămyntas</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)amu/ntas</foreign>. <sense id="n2403.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">The father of the Macedonian king Philip</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,021:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Reg. 2</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:7:4" default="NO"><author>Just.</author> 7, 4</bibl>.—Hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">Ămyntĭă-dēs</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <hi rend="ital">patr.</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a descendant of Amyntas</hi>, i. e. <hi rend="ital">Philip</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,010:297" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> Ib. 297</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n2403.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Name of a shepherd</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,001:3:66" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> E. 3, 66</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
amyntor: <entryFree id="n2404" type="main" key="A^myntor"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ămyntor</orth>, <itype>ŏris</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)amu/ntwr</foreign>, <sense id="n2404.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">king of the Dolopians</hi>, <hi rend="ital">and father of Phœnix</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:8:307" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 8, 307</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,002:3:27" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> H. 3, 27</bibl>.—Hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">Ămyn-tŏrĭdes</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">son of Amyntor</hi>, i. e. <hi rend="ital">Phœnix</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,004:1:337" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> A. A. 1, 337</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
amystis: <entryFree id="n2405" type="greek" key="a^mystis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ămystis</orth>, <itype>ĭdis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)/mustis</foreign>, <sense id="n2405.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the emptying of a cup at one draught</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:1:36:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 1, 36, 14</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
amythaon: <entryFree id="n2406" type="main" key="A^my_tha_o_n"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ămȳthāōn</orth> (also <orth extent="full" lang="la">Ămĭth-</orth>), <itype>ŏnis</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)amuqa/wn</foreign>, <sense id="n2406.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a Greek</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the father of Melampus</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:15:325" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 15, 325</bibl>.—Hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">Ămythāŏ-nĭus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <hi rend="ital">of Amythaon</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:3:550" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 3, 550</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:2:4:10" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 2, 4, 10</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
an: <entryFree id="n2407" type="main" key="a^n1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăn</orth>, <sense id="n2407.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">conj.</hi> [etym. very obscure; v. the various views adduced in Hand, I. p. 296, with which he seems dissatisfied; if it is connected with the Sanscr. anjas, = Germ. ander, = Engl. other, we may comp. the Engl. other and or with the Germ. oder, = or]. It introduces the second part of a disjunctive interrogation, or a phrase implying doubt, and thus unites in itself the signif. of aut and num or -ne, <hi rend="ital">or</hi>, <hi rend="ital">or whether</hi> (hence the clause with an is entirely parallel with that introduced by num, utrum, -ne, etc., while aut forms only a subdivision in the single disjunctive clause; utrum ... aut—an ... aut, whether ... or, etc.; cf. Ochsn. Eclog. p. 150; v. also aut). </sense><sense id="n2407.1" n="I" level="1"> In disjunctive interrogations. </sense><sense id="n2407.2" n="A" level="2"> Direct. </sense><sense id="n2407.3" n="a" level="4"> Introd. by <hi rend="ital">utrum</hi> (in Engl. the introd. particle <hi rend="ital">whether</hi> is now obsolete, and the interrogation is denoted simply by the order of the words): <cit><quote lang="la">Utrum hac me feriam an ab laevā latus?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,007:3:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Cist. 3, 10</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">sed utrum tu amicis hodie an inimicis tuis Daturu's cenam?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,016:3:2:88" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Ps. 3, 2, 88</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,014:3:1:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Pers. 3, 1, 13</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,019:1:2:138" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Trin. 1, 2, 138</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,006:2:4:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Cas. 2, 4, 11</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Utrum sit annon voltis?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,001:prol. 56" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Am. prol. 56</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quid facies? Utrum hoc tantum crimen praetermittes an obicies?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,004:30 sq" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Div. in Caecil. 30 sq.</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in plebem vero Romanam utrum superbiam prius commemorem an crudelitatem?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:chapter=122" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 1, 122</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,034:chapter=23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Deiot. 23</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:7:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 7, 13</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Utrum enim defenditis an impugnatis plebem?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:5:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 5, 3</bibl></cit>. —And with an twice: <cit><quote lang="la">Utrum hoc signum cupiditatis tuae an tropaeum necessitudinis atque hospitii an amoris indicium esse voluisti?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:chapter=115" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 115</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,009:57 sq" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Imp. Pomp. 57 sq.</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Rab. 21</bibl>.—With an three times: <cit><quote lang="la">Utrum res ab initio ita ducta est, an ad extremum ita perducta, an ita parva est pecunia, an is (homo) Verres, ut haec quae dixi, gratis facta esse videantur?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:chapter=61" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 61</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">3, 83</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,010:chapter=183" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Clu. 183</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:21:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 21, 10</bibl>; and seven times in <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,020:chapter=56" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Dom. 56</bibl>-58.—With <hi rend="ital">-ne</hi> <cb n="AN" /> pleon. (not to be confounded with cases where utrum precedes as <hi rend="ital">pron.;</hi> as <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:4:4:9" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 4, 4, 9</bibl>): <cit><quote lang="la">sed utrum tu masne an femina es, qui illum patrem voces?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,017:1:2:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Rud. 1, 2, 16</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,004:1:1:42" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Bacch. 1, 1, 42</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,018:5:4:26" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Stich. 5, 4, 26</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Utrum studione id sibi habet an laudi putat Fore, si etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,006:3:3:28" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Ad. 3, 3, 28</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Utrum igitur tandem perspicuisne dubia aperiuntur an dubiis perspicua tolluntur?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:4:24:67" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fin. 4, 24, 67</bibl></cit>.—And affixed to utrum, but rarely: <cit><quote lang="la">Utrumne jussi persequemur otium ... an hunc laborem etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,003:1:7" default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Epod. 1, 7</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:17:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 17, 1, 1, § 4</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:12:1:40" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 12, 1, 40</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n2407.4" n="b" level="4"> Introduced by <hi rend="ital">-ne</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">quid fit? seditio tabetne an numeros augificat suos?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0043,005:Rel. p. 23" default="NO"><author>Enn.</author> Trag. Rel. p. 23</bibl></cit> Rib.: <cit><quote lang="la">servos esne an liber?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,001:1:1:186" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Am. 1, 1, 186</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">idne agebas, ut tibi cum sceleratis an ut cum bonis civibus conveniret?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,033:chapter=18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Lig. 18</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">23</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">custosne urbis an direptor et vexator esset Antonius?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:3:27" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Phil. 3, 27</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,014:chapter=88" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Mur. 88</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,015:chapter=22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Sull. 22</bibl>.— <cit><quote lang="la">So with an twice,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,013:1:28" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Cat. 1, 28</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:16:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 16, 8</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">and five times,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,026:chapter=9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Balb. 9</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n2407.5" n="c" level="4"> Introduced by <hi rend="ital">nonne</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Nonne ad servos videtis rem publicam venturam fuisse? An mihi ipsi fuit mors aequo animo oppetenda?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,022:chapter=47" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Sest. 47</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Sex. Rosc. 43 sq.</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,020:chapter=26" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Dom. 26</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">127</bibl>.—So with an twice, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:11:36" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Phil. 11, 36</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n2407.6" n="d" level="4"> Introduced by <hi rend="ital">num</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">si quis invidiae metus, num est vehementius severitatis invidia quam inertiae pertimescenda?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,013:1:29" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Cat. 1, 29</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,014:chapter=76" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Mur. 76</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,022:chapter=80" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Sest. 80</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Num quid duas habetis patrias an est illa patria communis?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,044:2:2" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Leg. 2, 2</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n2407.7" n="e" level="4"> Without introductory particle: <cit><quote lang="la">quid igitur? haec vera an falsa sunt?</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Ac. 2, 29, 95</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quid enim exspectas? bellum an tabulas novas?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,013:2:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Cat. 2, 18</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ipse percussit an aliis occidendum dedit?</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Sex. Rosc. 74</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:chapter=106" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 2, 106</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,009:chapter=53" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Imp. Pomp. 53</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:2:27" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Phil. 2, 27</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">eloquar an sileam?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:3:37" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 3, 37</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">auditis an me ludit amabilis Insania?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:3:4:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 3, 4, 5</bibl></cit>.—So an twice, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,031:chapter=54" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Mil. 54</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">three times,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1318,001:2:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> Ep. 2, 8</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">and six times,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Rab. 14</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,027:chapter=40" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Pis. 40</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n2407.8" n="B" level="2"> Indirect. </sense><sense id="n2407.9" n="a" level="4"> Introduced by <hi rend="ital">utrum</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">quid tu, malum, curas, Utrum crudum an coctum edim?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,003:3:2:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Aul. 3, 2, 16</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,007:4:2:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Cist. 4, 2, 11</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,004:3:4:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Bacch. 3, 4, 1</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,012:2:3:74" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Mil. 2, 3, 74</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">quaero, si quis ... utrum is clemens an inhumanissimus esse videatur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,013:4:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Cat. 4, 12</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">agitur, utrum M. Antonio facultas detur an horum ei facere nihil liceat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:5:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Phil. 5, 6</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Sex. Rosc. 72</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,009:chapter=42" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Imp. Pomp. 42</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:chapter=105" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 1, 105</bibl>. !*? So once only in Vulg. aut for an: Loquimini de me utrum bovem cujusquam tulerim aut asinum, 1 Reg. 12, 3.—And with <hi rend="ital">-ne</hi> pleon.: <cit><quote lang="la">res in discrimine versatur, utrum possitne se contra luxuriem parsimonia defendere an deformata cupiditati addicatur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,001:chapter=92" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Quinct. 92</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">numquamne intelleges statuendum tibi esse, utrum illi, qui istam rem gesserunt, homicidaene sint an vindices libertatis?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:2:30" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Phil. 2, 30</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n2407.10" n="b" level="4"> Introduced by <hi rend="ital">-ne</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Fortunāne an forte repertus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0400,001:Trag. Rel. p. 159" default="NO"><author>Att.</author> Trag. Rel. p. 159</bibl></cit> Rib. agitur autem liberine vivamus an mortem obeamus, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:11:24" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Phil. 11, 24</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:4:73" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 4, 73</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,031:chapter=16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Mil. 16</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">nunc vero non id agitur, bonisne an malis moribus vivamus etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:C. 52:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> C. 52, 10</bibl></cit>.—So with an three times, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,040:chapter=61" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Or. 61</bibl>.— </sense><sense id="n2407.11" n="c" level="4"> Introduced by <hi rend="ital">an</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">haud scio an malim te videri ... an amicos tuos plus habuisse,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,027:chapter=39" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Pis. 39</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n2407.12" n="d" level="4"> Without introd. particle: <cit><quote lang="la">... vivam an moriar, nulla in me est metus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0043,005:Rel. p. 72" default="NO"><author>Enn.</author> Trag. Rel. p. 72</bibl></cit> Rib.: <cit><quote lang="la">vivat an mortuus sit, quis aut scit aut curat?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:13:33" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Phil. 13, 33</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">3, 18</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Sex. Rosc. 88</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,019:chapter=14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Red. in Sen. 14</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n2407.13" n="C" level="2"> Sometimes the opinion of the speaker or the probability inclines to the second interrogative clause (cf. infra, II. E.). and this is made emphatic, as a corrective of the former, <hi rend="ital">or rather</hi>, <hi rend="ital">or on the contrary</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ea quae dixi ad corpusne refers? an est aliquid, quod te suā sponte delectet?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:2:33:107" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fin. 2, 33, 107</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Cur sic agere voluistis? An ignoratis quod etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,001:44:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Gen. 44, 15</bibl></cit>.—Hence, in the comic poets, an potius: <cit><quote lang="la">cum animo depugnat suo, Utrum itane esse mavelit ut ... An ita potius ut etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,019:2:2:31" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Trin. 2, 2, 31</bibl></cit>: <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,018:1:2:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Stich. 1, 2, 18</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,019:2:2:25" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Trin. 2, 2, 25</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">an id flagitium est, An potius hoc patri aequomst fieri, ut a me ludatur dolis?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,003:2:3:94" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Eun. 2, 3, 94</bibl></cit>.— </sense><sense id="n2407.14" n="D" level="2"> The first part of the interrogation is freq. not expressed, but is to be supplied from the context; in this case, an begins the interrog., <hi rend="ital">or</hi>, <hi rend="ital">or rather</hi>, <hi rend="ital">or indeed</hi>, <hi rend="ital">or perhaps</hi> (but it does not begin an absolute, i. e. not disjunctive, interrog.): <hi rend="ital">De.</hi> Credam <cb n="AN" /> ego istuc, si esse te hilarem videro. <hi rend="ital">Ar.</hi> An tu esse me tristem putas? (where nonne me hilarem esse vides? is implied), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,002:5:1:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> As. 5, 1, 10</bibl>: <hi rend="ital">Ch.</hi> Sed Thaïs multon ante venit? <hi rend="ital">Py.</hi> An abiit jam a milite? <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,003:4:5:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Eun. 4, 5, 7</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">An ego Ulixem obliscar umquam?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0400,001:Trag. Rel. p. 199" default="NO"><author>Att.</author> Trag. Rel. p. 199</bibl></cit> Rib.: <cit><quote lang="la">An parum vobis est quod peccatis?</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Vulg.</author> Josh. 22, 17</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">est igitur aliquid, quod perturbata mens melius possit facere quam constans? an quisquam potest sine perturbatione mentis irasci?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:4:24:54" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 4, 24, 54</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,010:chapter=22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Clu. 22</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:3:29" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Off. 3, 29</bibl>: Debes hoc etiam rescribere, sit tibi curae Quantae conveniat Munatius; an male sarta Gratia nequiquam coit ... ? <hi rend="ital">or is perhaps</hi>, etc., <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 1, 3, 31</bibl> K. and H. —So esp. in Cic., in order to make the truth of an assertion more certain, by an argumentum a minore ad majus: <cit><quote lang="la">cur (philosophus) pecuniam magno opere desideret vel potius curet omnino? an Scythes Anacharsis potuit pro nihilo pecuniam ducere, nostrates philosophi non potuerunt?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:5:32:89 sq" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 5, 32, 89 sq.</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">An vero P. Scipio T. Gracchum privatus interfecit, Catilinam vero nos consules perferemus?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,013:1:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Cat. 1, 1</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,012:chapter=5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Rab. Perd. 5</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:14:5:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Phil. 14, 5, 12</bibl> Muret.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:1:2:5" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Fin. 1, 2, 5</bibl>, ubi v. Madv.—It sometimes introduces a question suggested by the words of another: <hi rend="ital">He.</hi> Mane. Non dum audisti, Demea, Quod est gravissimum? <hi rend="ital">De.</hi> An quid est etiam anplius? <hi rend="ital">Is there then</hi> etc., <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,006:3:4:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Ad. 3, 4, 21</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">sed ad haec, nisi molestum est, habeo quae velim. An me, inquam, nisi te audire vellem censes haec dicturum fuisse?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:1:8:28" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fin. 1, 8, 28</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">2, 22, 74</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:5:26:73" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tusc. 5, 26, 73</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">5, 12, 35</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,039:chapter=184" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Brut. 184</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,054:2:4" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Fat. 2, 4</bibl>; v. Madv. ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:1:8:28" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fin. 1, 8, 28</bibl>.—It sometimes anticipates an answer to something going before: At vero si ad vitem sensus accesserit, ut appetitum quendam habeat et per se ipsa moveatur, quid facturam putas? An ea, quae per vinitorem antea consequebatur, per se ipsa curabit? <hi rend="ital">shall we not say that</hi>, <hi rend="ital">must we not think that</hi> etc., <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:5:14:38" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fin. 5, 14, 38</bibl>, ubi v. Madv.— </sense><sense id="n2407.15" n="E" level="2"> An non. and in one word, annon (in direct questions more freq. than necne): <cit><quote lang="la">isne est quem quaero an non?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,004:5:6:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Phorm. 5, 6, 12</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Hocine agis an non?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:1:2:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> And. 1, 2, 15</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Tibi ego dico an non?</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 4, 4, 23</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">utrum sit an non voltis?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,001:prol. 56" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Am. prol. 56</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">utrum cetera nomina in codicem accepti et expensi digesta habes annon?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,003:3 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Rosc. Com. 3 al.</bibl></cit>—Also in indirect questions = necne, q. v.: <cit><quote lang="la">abi, vise redieritne jam an non dum domum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,004:3:4:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Phorm. 3, 4, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">videbo utrum clamorem opere conpleverint, an non est ita,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,001:18:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Gen. 18, 21</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">24, 21</bibl>.— </sense><sense id="n2407.16" n="F" level="1"> An ne, usually written anne, pleon. for an. </sense><sense id="n2407.17" n="a" level="4"> In direct questions: <cit><quote lang="la">anne tu dicis quā ex causā vindicaveris?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,014:chapter=26" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Mur. 26</bibl></cit>. —</sense><sense id="n2407.18" n="b" level="4"> In indirect questions: <cit><quote lang="la">nec. aequom anne iniquom imperet, cogitabit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,001:1:1:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Am. 1, 1, 19</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,016:1:1:122" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Ps. 1, 1, 122</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">percontarier, Utrum aurum reddat anne eat secum simul,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,004:4:1:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Bacch. 4, 1, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Nam quid ego de consulato loquar, parto vis, anue gesto?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,027:1:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Pis. 1, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum interrogetur, tria pauca sint anne multa,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Ac. 2, 29</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Gabinio dicam anne Pompeio, an utrique,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,009:19:57" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Imp. Pomp. 19, 57</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,040:61:206" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Or. 61, 206</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Quid enim interest, divitias, opes, valetudinem bona dicas anne praeposita, cum etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:4:9:23" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Fin. 4, 9, 23</bibl></cit> Madv.; August. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=aug.:69 al" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Aug. 69 al.</bibl> (for the omission of the second disjunctive clause or the particle necne representing it, v. utrum; <cit><quote lang="la">instances of this usage in eccl. Lat. are,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,003:13:36" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Lev. 13, 36</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">14, 36</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,004:11:23 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Num. 11, 23 al.</bibl>).—</sense><sense id="n2407.19" n="II" level="1"> In disjunctive clauses that express doubt, <hi rend="ital">or.</hi> </sense><sense id="n2407.20" n="A" level="2"> Utrum stultitiā facere ego hunc an malitiā Dicam, scientem an imprudentem, incertus sum. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,004:4:3:54" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Phorm. 4, 3, 54</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut nescias, utrum res oratione an verba sententiis illustrentur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:2:13:56" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 2, 13, 56</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">honestumne factu sit an turpe, dubitant,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:1:3:9" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Off. 1, 3, 9</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nescio, gratulerne tibi an timeam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:2:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 2, 5</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:7:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 7, 5</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">pecuniae an famae minus parceret, haud facile discerneres,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:C. 25:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> C. 25, 3</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:ib. 52:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> ib. 52, 10</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=aug.:19" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Aug. 19</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=tib.:10" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tib. 10</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=cl.:15" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Claud. 15</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">cognoscet de doctrinā, utrum ex Deo sit an ego a me ipso loquar,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,004:7:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Joan. 7, 17</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,030:2:19 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Eccl. 2, 19 al.</bibl>—</sense><sense id="n2407.21" n="B" level="2"> An sometimes denotes uncertainty by itself, without a verb of doubting (dubito, dubium or incertum est, etc., vet in such cases the editors are divided between an and aut; cf. Mos. and Orell. ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,043:1:12" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Rep. 1, 12</bibl>): verene hoc memoriae proditum est <pb n="115" /> <cb n="AN" /> regem istum Numam Pythagorae ipsius discipulum, an certe Pythagoreum fuisse? <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,043:2:15" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Rep. 2, 15</bibl>, where B. and K. read <hi rend="ital">aut</hi> certe: Cn. Octavius est an Cn. Cornelius quidam tuus familiaris, summo genere natus, terrae filius; <cit><quote lang="la">is etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:7:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 7, 9</bibl></cit> B. and K.: <cit><quote lang="la">Themistocles quidem, cum ei Simonides an quis alius artem memoriae polliceretur, Oblivionis, inquit, mallem,</quote> <trans><tr>Simonides or some other person</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:2:32:104" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Fin. 2, 32, 104</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:7:9:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 7, 9, 3</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:1:3:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 1, 3, 2</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">2, 7, 3</bibl>; v. Madv. ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:2:32:104" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fin. 2, 32, 104</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n2407.22" n="C" level="2"> It often stands for sive (so esp. in and after the Aug. per.): <cit><quote lang="la">quod sit an non, nihil commovet analogiam,</quote> <trans><tr>whether this be so or not</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:L. L. 9:section=105" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> L. L. 9, § 105</bibl></cit> Müll.; Att. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Prisc.</author> p. 677</bibl> P.; <bibl default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> R. Am. 797</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">saucius an sanus, numquid tua signa reliqui,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,007:4:7" default="NO"><author>id.</author> F. 4, 7</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Illa mihi referet, si nostri mutua curast, An minor, an toto pectore deciderim,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0660,001:3:1:20" default="NO"><author>Tib.</author> 3, 1, 20</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:11:26" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 11, 26</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">sive nullam opem praevidebat inermis atque exul, seu taedio ambiguae spei an amore conjugis et liberorum,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 14, 59</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n2407.23" n="D" level="2"> The first disjunctive clause is freq. to be supplied from the gen. idea or an may stand for utrum—necne (cf. supra, I. D.): <cit><quote lang="la">qui scis, an, quae jubeam, sine vi faciat? (vine coactus is to be supplied),</quote> <trans><tr>how knowest thou whether or not he will do it without compulsion?</tr></trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,003:4:7:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Eun. 4, 7, 20</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">An dolo malo factum sit, ambigitur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,006:chapter=23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Tull. 23</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quaesivi an misisset (periplasmata),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:4:27" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 4, 27</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Vide an facile fieri tu potueris, cum etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,062:B. 13:2:1" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Fragm. B. 13, 2, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">praebete aurem et videte an mentiar,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Vulg.</author> Job, 6, 28</bibl></cit>: de L. Bruto fortasse dubitaverim an propter infinitum odium tyranni effrenatius in Aruntem invaserit, <hi rend="ital">I might doubt whether or not</hi>, etc., <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:4:22:50" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 4, 22, 50</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:3:76" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 3, 76</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Quis scit an adiciant hodiernae crastina summae Tempora di superi?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:4:7:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 4, 7, 17</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1318,001:6:21:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> Ep. 6, 21, 3</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:2:17:38" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 2, 17, 38</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Sine videamus an veniat Elias,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,001:27:49" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Matt. 27, 49</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">tria sine dubio rursus spectanda sunt, an sit, quid sit, quale sit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:5:10:53" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 5, 10, 53</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">dubium an quaesitā morte,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:1:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 1, 5</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">6, 50</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">4, 74</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Multitudo an vindicatura Bessum fuerit, incertum est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:7:5" default="NO"><author>Curt.</author> 7, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">diu Lacedaemonii, an eum summae rei praeponerent, deliberaverunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:6:2:4" default="NO"><author>Just.</author> 6, 2, 4</bibl></cit> et saep.— </sense><sense id="n2407.24" n="E" level="2"> Since in such distrib. sentences expressive of doubt, the opinion of the speaker or the probability usually inclines to the second, i. e. to the clause beginning with <hi rend="ital">an</hi>, the expressions haud scio an, nescio an, dubito an (the latter through all pers. and tenses), incline to an affirmative signification, <hi rend="ital">I almost know</hi>, <hi rend="ital">I am inclined to think</hi>, <hi rend="ital">I almost think</hi>, <hi rend="ital">I might say</hi>, <hi rend="ital">I might assert that</hi>, etc., for <hi rend="ital">perhaps</hi>, <hi rend="ital">probably</hi> (hence the opinion is incorrect that an, in this situation, stands for an non; for by an non a negation of the objective clause is expressed, e. g. nescio an non beatus sit, <hi rend="ital">I am almost of the opinion that he is not happy</hi>, <xr><lbl>v.</lbl> <ref type="sym" targOrder="U">infra</ref></xr>, and cf. Beier ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:chapter=1" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 1</bibl>, Exc. XI. p. 335 sq.; Cic. uses haud scio an eleven times in his Orations; <cit><quote lang="la">nescio an, four times): atque haud scio an, quae dixit sint vera omnia,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:3:2:45" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> And. 3, 2, 45</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">crudele gladiatorum spectaculum et inhumanum non nullis videri solet: et haud scio an ita sit, ut nunc fit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:2:17:41" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 2, 17, 41</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Fl. 26</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">testem non mediocrem, sed haud scio an gravissimum,</quote> <trans><tr>perhaps</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:3:29" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Off. 3, 29</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">constantiam dico? nescio an melius patientiam possim dicere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,033:chapter=9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Lig. 9</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:9:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 9, 19</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ingens eo die res, ac nescio an maxima illo bello gesta sit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:23:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 23, 16</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:12:11:7 al" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 12, 11, 7 al.</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">si per se virtus sine fortunā ponderanda sit, dubito an Thrasybulum primum omuium ponam,</quote> <trans><tr>I am not certain whether I should not prefer Thrasybulus to all others</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,001:Thras. 1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Thras. 1</bibl></cit> Dähne: <cit><quote lang="la">dicitur acinace stricto Darius dubitāsse an fugae dedecus honestā morte vitaret,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>was almost resolved upon</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:4:5:30" default="NO"><author>Curt.</author> 4, 5, 30</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ego dubito an id improprium potius appellem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:1:5:46" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 1, 5, 46</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:1:3 al" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 1, 3 al.</bibl>—Hence, a neg. objective clause must contain in this connection the words non, nemo, nullus, nihil, numquam, nusquam, etc.: <cit><quote lang="la">dubitet an turpe non sit,</quote> <trans><tr>he is inclined to believe that it is not bad</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:3:12:50" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 3, 12, 50</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">haud scio an ne opus quidem sit, nihil umquam deesse amicis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,052:14:51" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Am. 14, 51</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">eloquentiā quidem nescio an habuisset parem neminem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,039:chapter=33" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Brut. 33</bibl></cit>: quod cum omnibus est faciendum tum haud scio an nemini potius quam tibi, <hi rend="ital">to no one perhaps more</hi>, id. <cb n="ANAD" /> Off. 3, 2, 6: <cit><quote lang="la">meā sententiā haud scio an nulla beatior esse possit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,051:chapter=16" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Sen. 16</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,044:1:21" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Leg. 1, 21</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">non saepe atque haud scio an numquam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,040:2:7 al" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Or. 2, 7 al.</bibl></cit>—</sense><sense id="n2407.25" n="F" level="1"> Sometimes the distributive clause beginning with <hi rend="ital">an</hi> designates directly the opposite, the more improbable, the negative; in which case nescio an, haud scio an, etc., like the Engl. <hi rend="ital">I know not whether</hi>, signify <hi rend="ital">I think that not</hi>, <hi rend="ital">I believe that not</hi>, etc.; hence, in the object. clause, aliquis, quisquam, ullus, etc., must stand instead of nemo, nullus, etc. (so for the most part only after Cic.): an profecturus sim, nescio, <hi rend="ital">I know not</hi> (i. e. <hi rend="ital">I doubt</hi>, <hi rend="ital">I am not confident</hi>) <hi rend="ital">whether I shall effect any thing</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Ep. 25" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Ep. 25</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">opus nescio an superabile, magnum certe tractemus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Q. N. 3" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Q. N. 3</bibl></cit>, praef. 4; Caecil. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:6:7:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 6, 7, 6</bibl>: haud scio an vivere nobis liceret, <hi rend="ital">I know not whether we</hi>, etc., <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,021:11:22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Har. Resp. 11, 22</bibl>: doleo enim maximam feminam eripi oculis civitatis, nescio an aliquid simile visuris, for <hi rend="ital">I know not whether they will ever see any thing of this kind</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1318,001:7:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> Ep. 7, 19</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1038,001:5:2:9" default="NO"><author>Val. Max.</author> 5, 2, 9</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">nescio an ullum tempus jucundius exegerim,</quote> <trans><tr>I do not know whether I have ever passed time more pleasantly</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1038,001:3:1" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 3, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">namque huic uni contigit, quod nescio an ulli,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,020:1:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Timol. 1, 1</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Contr. 3 praef" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Contr. 3 praef.</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:9:4:1" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 9, 4, 1</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">nostri quoque soloecum, soloecismum nescio an umquam dixerint,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:5:20 al" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 5, 20 al.</bibl></cit> Cf. upon this word Hand, Turs. I. pp. 296-361, and Beier, Exc. ad Cic. Am. pp. 202-238.</sense></entryFree>
<entryFree id="n2408" type="main" key="an2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">an-</orth>, v. ambi.</entryFree>

<entryFree id="n2409" type="main" key="a^n3" n="3"><orth extent="full" lang="la">-ăn</orth>. This word appears in forsan, forsitan, and fortasse an (<bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0400,001:Trag. Rel. p. 151" default="NO"><author>Att.</author> Trag. Rel. p. 151</bibl> Rib.) or fortassan, seeming to enhance the idea of uncertainty and doubt belonging to fors, etc., and is regarded by some as the Greek conditional particle <foreign lang="greek">a)/n</foreign>, and indeed one of these compounds, forsitan, sometimes in the Vulgate, translates <foreign lang="greek">a)/n</foreign>; as, Joan. 4, 10; 5, 46; 8, 19; and in 3, Joan. 9, it still represents the various reading, <foreign lang="greek">a)/n</foreign>.</entryFree>
anabaptismus: <entryFree id="n2410" type="greek" key="a^na^baptismus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ănăbaptismus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)nabaptismo/s</foreign>, <sense id="n2410.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a second baptism</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2468,001:ad Psa. 38" default="NO"><author>Aug.</author> ad Psa. 38</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
anabasis: <entryFree id="n2411" type="greek" key="a^na^ba^si^s"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ănăbăsĭs</orth>, <itype>is</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)na/basis</foreign>, <sense id="n2411.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a plant</hi>, <hi rend="ital">horse-tail</hi>: equisetum, Linn.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:26:36" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 26, 7, 20, § 36</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:26:133" default="NO" valid="yes">26, 13, 83, § 133</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
anabathrum: <entryFree id="n2412" type="greek" key="a^na^bathrum"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ănăbathrum</orth>, i. <gen>n.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)na/baqron</foreign>, <sense id="n2412.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">an elevated place for beholding public games</hi>: quae conducto pendent anabathra tigillo, <hi rend="ital">tiers of benches that rest on hired beams</hi>, * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:7:46" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 7, 46</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
anabolium: <entryFree id="n2413" type="gloss" key="a^na^bo^lium"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ănăbŏlium</orth>, <itype>ii</itype>, <gen>n.</gen> <etym><foreign lang="greek">a)naba/llw</foreign></etym>, <sense id="n2413.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a surgical instrument</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Inscr. Orell.</author> 1572</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
anacampseros: <entryFree id="n2414" type="main" key="a^na^campse^ro_s"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ănăcampsĕrōs</orth>, <itype>ōtis</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)nakamye/rws</foreign> (love-restoring), <sense id="n2414.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">an herb</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the touch of which was said to have the power of bringing back lost love</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:24:167" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 24, 17, 102, § 167</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
anaces: <entryFree id="n2415" type="greek" key="A^na^ces"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ănăces</orth>, <itype>um</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)/anakes</foreign> (v. <foreign lang="greek">a)/nac</foreign>, L. and S.), <sense id="n2415.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">an epithet of the Dioscuri</hi> (<hi rend="ital">Castor and Pollux</hi>), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:3:21" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 3, 21</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
anacharsis: <entryFree id="n2416" type="greek" key="A^na^charsis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ănăcharsis</orth>, <itype>is</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)ana/xarsis</foreign>, <sense id="n2416.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a distinguished Scythian philosopher in the time of Solon</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:5:32:90" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 5, 32, 90</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:7:209 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 7, 56, 57, § 209 al.</bibl></sense></entryFree>
anachites: <entryFree id="n2417" type="greek" key="a^na^chi_tes"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ănăchītes</orth>, v. anancites.</entryFree>
anachoresis: <entryFree id="n2418" type="greek" key="a^na^cho_re_sis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ănăchōrēsis</orth>, <itype>is or eos</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)naxw/rhsis</foreign>, <sense id="n2418.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">retirement</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the life of an eremite</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Sid.</author> Ep. 7, 9</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
anachoreta: <entryFree id="n2419" type="greek" key="a^na^cho_re_ta"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ănăchōrēta</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)naxwrhth/s</foreign>, <sense id="n2419.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a hermit</hi>, <hi rend="ital">an eremite</hi>, <hi rend="ital">recluse</hi>, <hi rend="ital">anchorite</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Sulp.</author> Sev. Dial. 1, 18</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Sid.</author> Carm. 16, 97</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
anaclinterium: <entryFree id="n2420" type="greek" key="a^na^clinte_ri^um"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ănăclintērĭum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)naklinth/rion</foreign>, <sense id="n2420.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a cushion for leaning upon</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Spart.</author> Ael. Ver. 5</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
anacreon: <entryFree id="n2421" type="main" key="A^na_^cre^o_n"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ănā^crĕōn</orth>, <itype>ontis</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)anakre/wn</foreign>, <sense id="n2421.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a distinguished lyric poet of Teos</hi>, <hi rend="ital">who fl.</hi> 540 B.C., <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:4:33:71" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 4, 33, 71</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:4:9:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 4, 9, 9</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,003:14:10 al" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Epod. 14, 10 al.</bibl>—Hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">Ănā^crĕōntēus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Diom.</author> p. 512</bibl> P.; <orth extent="full" lang="la">Ănā^crĕōn-tĭus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:9:4:78" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 9, 4, 78</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:19:9" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 19, 9</bibl>; and <orth extent="full" lang="la">Ănā^crĕōntĭcus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Fulg.</author> Myth. 1</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
anactorium: <entryFree id="n2422" type="greek" key="a^nacto^ri^um"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ănactŏrĭum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)nakto/rion</foreign>, <sense id="n2422.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a plant</hi>, <hi rend="ital">sword-grass</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> Herb. 78</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
anadema: <entryFree id="n2423" type="greek" key="a^na^de_ma^"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ănădēmă</orth>, <itype>ătis</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)na/dhma</foreign>, <sense id="n2423.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a band</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a fillet</hi>, <hi rend="ital">an ornament for the head</hi>: Et bene parta patrum flunt anademata, mitrae, <hi rend="ital">the well-earned property of fathers is converted into head-bands</hi>, etc., * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:4:1129" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 4, 1129</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:34:2:27" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 34, 2, 27</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
anadiplosis: <entryFree id="n2424" type="greek" key="a^na^diplo_sis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ănădiplōsis</orth>, <itype>is or eos</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)nadi/plwsis</foreign>,<cb n="ANAP" />  <sense id="n2424.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the reduplication</hi> or <hi rend="ital">repetition of the same word</hi> (in pure Lat., conduplicatio); <cit><quote lang="la">as, Sequitur pulcherrimus Astur, Astur equo fidens,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:10:181" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 10, 181</bibl></cit>; cf. Aquila, Rom. 32; Jul. <bibl default="NO"><author>Rufin.</author> 7</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Mart. Cap.</author> 5, 175</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
anadyomene: <entryFree id="n2425" type="greek" key="A^na^dy^o^me^ne_"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ănădyŏmĕnē</orth>, <itype>ēs</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)naduome/nh</foreign> (she that emerges), <sense id="n2425.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">an epithet of Venus emerging from the sea</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a celebrated picture of the painter Apelles</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:35:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 35, 10, 36, § 12</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
anagallis: <entryFree id="n2426" type="greek" key="a^na^gallis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ănăgallis</orth>, <itype>ĭdis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a/nagalli/s</foreign>, <sense id="n2426.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a plant</hi>, <hi rend="ital">pimpernel</hi> or <hi rend="ital">chickweed</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:25:144" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 25, 13, 92, § 144</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
anaglypticus: <entryFree id="n2427" type="greek" key="a^na^glypti^cus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ănăglyptĭcus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)nagluptiko/s</foreign>, <sense id="n2427.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">carved</hi> or <hi rend="ital">engraved in bas-relief</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">metallum,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Sid.</author> Ep. 9, 13</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
anaglyptus: <entryFree id="n2428" type="greek" key="a^na^glyptus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ănăglyptus</orth> or <orth extent="full" lang="la">-phus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)na/gluptos</foreign> or <foreign lang="greek">-fos</foreign>; in sculpture, <sense id="n2428.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">wrought</hi> or <hi rend="ital">carved in bas-relief</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Inscr. Orell.</author> 3838</bibl>.— Hence, <hi rend="ital">subst.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">ănăglypta</orth>, <itype>ōrum</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">work in bas-relief</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:33:139" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 33, 11, 49, § 139</bibl>, where the old form was <hi rend="ital">anaglypha.</hi></sense></entryFree>
anagnia: <entryFree id="n2429" type="main" key="A^nagni^a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ănagnĭa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)anagni/a</foreign>, <sense id="n2429.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a town in Latium</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the chief seat of the Hernici</hi>, now <hi rend="ital">Anagni</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:16:8:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 16, 8, 1</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:45:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 45, 16</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:34:23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 34, 6, 11, § 23</bibl>; cf. Mann. Ital. 1, 665.—Hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">Ănagnīnus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <hi rend="ital">belonging to Anagnia</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,020:chapter=30" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Dom. 30</bibl>.—<hi rend="ital">Subst.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">Ănagnīnum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">an estate near Anagnia</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:12:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 12, 1</bibl>. —<hi rend="ital">Plur.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">Ănagnīni</orth>, <itype>ōrum</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">its inhabitants</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:2:41" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Phil. 2, 41</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:3:63" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 3, 5, 9, § 63</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
anagnostes: <entryFree id="n2430" type="greek" key="a^na^gnoste_s"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ănăgnostēs</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)nagnw/sths</foreign>, <sense id="n2430.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a reader</hi>, com. among the ancients an educated slave (cf. acroama): <cit><quote lang="la">noster,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:1:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 1, 12</bibl></cit>, where Orell. would write it as Greek; Vatin. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:5:9:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 5, 9, 2</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,025:13:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Att. 13, 14</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:3:19" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 3, 19</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:18:5" default="NO">18, 5</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
anagyros: <entryFree id="n2431" type="greek" key="a^na^gy_ros"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ănăgȳros</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)na/guros</foreign>, <sense id="n2431.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a strengscented</hi>, <hi rend="ital">pod-bearing shrub</hi>, <hi rend="ital">bean-trefoil</hi>: Anagyris foetida, Linn.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:27:30" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 27, 4, 13, § 30</bibl></sense></entryFree>
anaitis: <entryFree id="n2432" type="main" key="A^na^i_tis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ănăītis</orth>, <itype>ĭdis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, <sense id="n2432.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">an Armenian goddess</hi>, said to be the name of Diana read backwards (Anaid), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:33:84" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 33, 4, 24, § 84</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
analecta: <entryFree id="n2433" type="main" key="a^na^lecta"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ănălecta</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)nale/kths</foreign>, <sense id="n2433.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">he that collected the crumbs</hi>, etc., <hi rend="ital">left after a meal</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:7:20" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 7, 20</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:14:82" default="NO">14, 82</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n2433.1" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>: grammaticos habere analectas, <hi rend="ital">that picked up words</hi> (said of parasites), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Ep. 27" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Ep. 27</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
analectris: <entryFree id="n2434" type="hapax" key="a^na^lectris"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ănălectris</orth>, <itype>ĭdis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym><foreign lang="greek">a)na/-le/ktron</foreign></etym>, perh. <sense id="n2434.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a cushion for the shoulders</hi>, <hi rend="ital">used to improve the figure</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a shoulder-pad</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,004:3:273" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> A. A. 3, 273</bibl>, where Merkel reads <hi rend="ital">analeptrides;</hi> v. analeptris.</sense></entryFree>
analemma: <entryFree id="n2435" type="greek" key="a^na^lemma^"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ănălemmă</orth>, <itype>ătis</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)na/lhmma</foreign>, <sense id="n2435.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a sundial which showed the latitude and meridian of a place</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1056,001:9:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vitr.</author> 9, 4</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
analeptris: <entryFree id="n2436" type="main" key="a^na^leptris"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ănăleptris</orth>, <itype>ĭdis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)nalhptri/s</foreign> (<foreign lang="greek">a)nalamba/nw</foreign>, to hold up), <sense id="n2436.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a suspensory bandage</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,004:3:273" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> A. A. 3, 273</bibl> Merkel; v. analectris.</sense></entryFree>
analogia: <entryFree id="n2437" type="greek" key="a^na^lo^gi^a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ănălŏgĭa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)nalogi/a</foreign>, <sense id="n2437.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the resemblance</hi> or <hi rend="ital">agreement of several things;</hi> in gram., <hi rend="ital">the analogy of language</hi>, <hi rend="ital">analogy</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:L. L. 9:4 al" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> L. L. 9, 4 al.</bibl> (in <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:6:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 6, 2</bibl>, written as Greek).</sense></entryFree>
analogicus: <entryFree id="n2438" type="greek" key="a^na^lo^gi^cus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ănălŏgĭcus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>analogia</etym>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)nalogiko/s</foreign>, <sense id="n2438.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">pertaining to analogy</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">in libris analogicis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:4:16" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 4, 16</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
analogus: <entryFree id="n2439" type="greek" key="a^na^lo^gus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ănălŏgus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)na/logos</foreign>, <sense id="n2439.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">analogous</hi>, <hi rend="ital">proportionate</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:L. L. 10:section=37" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> L. L. 10, § 37</bibl> (by Müll. written as Greek).</sense></entryFree>
anancaeum: <entryFree id="n2440" type="greek" key="a^nancaeum"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ănancaeum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)nagkai=on</foreign> (that must be done), <sense id="n2440.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a large drinking-cup</hi>, <hi rend="ital">which must be drained on a wager</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a brimmer</hi> or <hi rend="ital">bowl</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,017:2:3:33" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Rud. 2, 3, 33</bibl>; Varr. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> p. 547, 33</bibl> dub.</sense></entryFree>
anancites: <entryFree id="n2441" type="main" key="a^nanci_tes"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ănancītes</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <etym><foreign lang="greek">a)n- a)/gxw</foreign>, to free from distress</etym>, <sense id="n2441.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a name of the diamond as a remedy for sadness and trouble of mind</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">adamas et venena vincit et lymphationes abigit metusque vanos expellit a mente. Ob id quidam eum ananciten vocavere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:37:61" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 37, 4, 15, § 61</bibl></cit> Sillig, Jan; the old reading here was <hi rend="ital">anachiten.</hi></sense></entryFree>
anancitis: <entryFree id="n2442" type="greek" key="a^nanci_tis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ănancītis</orth>, <itype>ĭdis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, <sense id="n2442.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a precious stone used in hydromancy</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Anancitide in hydromantiā dicunt evocari imagines deorum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:37:192" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 37, 11, 73, § 192</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
anapaesticus: <entryFree id="n2443" type="main" key="a^na^paesti^cus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ănăpaestĭcus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>anapaestus</etym>, <sense id="n2443.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">consisting of anapœsts</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Sid.</author> Ep. 4, 3</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Serv.</author> ad Verg. E. 8, 78</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
anapaestus: <entryFree id="n2444" type="greek" key="a^na^paestus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ănăpaestus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)na/paistos</foreign> (struck back). <sense id="n2444.0" n="I" level="1"> Pes, <hi rend="ital">the metrical foot</hi>, <hi rend="ital">anapœst</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">˘˘¯ (i. e. a reversed dactyl),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:2:16:37" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 2, 16, 37</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:3:47" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> de Or. 3, 47</bibl>; also <hi rend="ital">absol.</hi> without pes, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,040:chapter=56" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Or. 56</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n2444.1" n="II" level="1"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">ănă-paestum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen> (sc. carmen), <hi rend="ital">a poem in</hi> <pb n="116" /> <cb n="ANAT" /> <hi rend="ital">anapœsts</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:3:24:57" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 3, 24, 57</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,040:chapter=56" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Or. 56</bibl>; Gell. praef. 20.</sense></entryFree>
anapauomene: <entryFree id="n2445" type="greek" key="A^na^pauo^me^ne_"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ănăpauŏmĕnē</orth>, <itype>ēs</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)napauome/nh</foreign> (she that rests), <sense id="n2445.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a painting of the Theban Aristides</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:35:99" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 35, 10, 36, § 99</bibl>; cf. Anapauomenos.</sense></entryFree>
anapauomenos: <entryFree id="n2446" type="greek" key="A^na^pauo^me^nos"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ănăpauŏmĕnos</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)napauo/menos</foreign> (he that rests), <sense id="n2446.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a painting of Protogenes</hi>, <hi rend="ital">which represents a satyr as leaning idly against a tree</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:35:106" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 35, 10, 36, § 106</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
