anaphe: <entryFree id="n2447" type="main" key="A^na^phe_"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ănăphē</orth>, <itype>ēs</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)ana/fh</foreign>, <sense id="n2447.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">an island that rose of itself</hi> (i. e. volcanic) <hi rend="ital">in the Cretan Sea</hi>, now <hi rend="ital">Namfi</hi> or <hi rend="ital">Namfio</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:7:461" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 7, 461</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:2:202" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 2, 87, 89, § 202</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Amm.</author> 17, 7</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
anaphora: <entryFree id="n2448" type="greek" key="a^na^pho^ra^"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ănăphŏră</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)nafora/</foreign>. <sense id="n2448.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A rising</hi> or <hi rend="ital">mounting up</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the rising of the stars</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:7:160" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 7, 49, 50, § 160</bibl>; Firm. Math. 3, 3. —</sense><sense id="n2448.1" n="II" level="1"> In rhet. </sense><sense id="n2448.2" n="A" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">The bringing up</hi> or <hi rend="ital">repetition of a word at the beginning of successive clauses</hi>, e. g. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:2:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 2, 10</bibl>: Verres calumniatores apponebat, Verres adesse jubebat, Verres cognoscebat, etc., Don. p. 1773 P.; <bibl default="NO"><author>Charis.</author> p. 250</bibl> P.; <bibl default="NO"><author>Diom.</author> p. 440</bibl> P.—</sense><sense id="n2448.3" n="B" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">The improper reference of a word to a preceding word</hi>, e. g. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:C. 18:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> C. 18, 1</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">conjuravere pauci, in quibus Catilina: de quā (sc. conjuratione), etc.,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Diom.</author> p. 440</bibl></cit> P. (Kritz here reads <hi rend="ital">de quo;</hi> cf. Kritz ad h. l.).</sense></entryFree>
anaphoricus: <entryFree id="n2449" type="greek" key="a^na^pho^ri^cus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ănăphŏrĭcus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)naforiko/s</foreign>. <sense id="n2449.0" n="I" level="1"> In astronomy, <hi rend="ital">adjusted according to the rising of the stars</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">horologium,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1056,001:9:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vitr.</author> 9, 9</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n2449.1" n="II" level="1"> In medicine, <hi rend="ital">bringing up blood</hi>, <hi rend="ital">spitting blood</hi>, Firm. Math. 3, 13.</sense></entryFree>
anapis: <entryFree id="n2450" type="main" key="A^na_pis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ănāpis</orth>, <itype>is</itype>, or <orth extent="full" lang="la">-us</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <sense id="n2450.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Brother of Amphinomus</hi>, q. v.—</sense><sense id="n2450.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A river in Sicily</hi>, <hi rend="ital">which empties into the bay of Syracuse</hi>, now <hi rend="ital">Anapo</hi> or <hi rend="ital">Fiume di Sortino</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:5:417" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 5, 417</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,007:4:469" default="NO"><author>id.</author> F. 4, 469</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
anapleroticus: <entryFree id="n2451" type="greek" key="a^na^ple_ro_ti^cus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ănăplērōtĭcus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)naplhrwtiko/s</foreign>, <sense id="n2451.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">suitable for filling up</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Veg.</author> Vet. 2, 26</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
anapus: <entryFree id="n2452" type="main" key="A^na_pus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ănāpus</orth>, v. Anapis.</entryFree>
anarrhinon: <entryFree id="n2453" type="main" key="a^narrhi_non"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ănarrhīnon</orth>, v. antirrhinon.</entryFree>
anartes: <entryFree id="n2454" type="main" key="Anartes"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Anartes</orth>, <itype>ium</itype>, or <orth extent="full" lang="la">Anarti</orth>, <itype>ōrum</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n2454.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a people in Transylvania</hi>, <hi rend="ital">on the Theis</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:6:25" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 6, 25</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
anas: <entryFree id="n2455" type="main" key="a^na^s1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ănăs</orth>, <itype>ănătis</itype> (<sense id="n2455.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">gen. plur.</hi> anatum, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:2:48:124" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 2, 48, 124</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:25:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 25, 2, 3, § 6</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">rarely anatium,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 3:5:14" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 3, 5, 14</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:3:11:1" default="NO">3, 11, 1</bibl>) [kindr. with old Germ. Anut; Lith. antis; mod. Germ. Ente; perh. also with Sanscr. ātis, a waterfowl], <gen>f.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">the duck</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">greges anatium,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 3:11" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 3, 11</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">anatum ova,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:2:48:124 al" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 2, 48, 124 al.</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Anas fluviatilis,</quote> <trans><tr>wild-duck</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:11:773" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 11, 773</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>

<entryFree id="n2456" type="main" key="a^na_s2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ănās</orth>, <itype>ātis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>3. anus</etym>, <sense id="n2456.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">disease of old women</hi>: anatem morbum anuum dicebant, id est, vetularum sicut senium morbum senum, Paul. ex Fest, p. 29 Müll.; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>Placid.</author> p. 435</bibl> Mai.</sense></entryFree>

<entryFree id="n2457" type="main" key="A^nas3" n="3"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ănas</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n2457.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a river in Spain</hi>, now <hi rend="ital">Guadiana</hi> (Arab., i. e. Wadi-Ana, = river Anas), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:1:38" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. C. 1, 38</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:3:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 3, 1, 3, § 3</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:4:116" default="NO" valid="yes">4, 22, 35, § 116</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0929,001:2:6" default="NO"><author>Mel.</author> 2, 6</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0929,001:3:1" default="NO">3, 1</bibl>; cf. Mann. Hispan. 325.</sense></entryFree>
anassum: <entryFree id="n2458" type="main" key="Anassum"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Anassum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, <sense id="n2458.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a small river in the Venetian territory</hi>, now <hi rend="ital">Stella</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:3:126" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 3, 18, 22, § 126</bibl> Hard.; <hi rend="ital">Anaxum</hi>, Jan; cf. Mann. Ital. 1, 82.</sense></entryFree>
anatarius: <entryFree id="n2459" type="main" key="a^na^ta_ri^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ănătārĭus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>anas</etym>, <sense id="n2459.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">relating to a duck</hi>: aquila, <hi rend="ital">the duck-eagle</hi>, which stations itself by the water and carries off ducks: Falco haliaëtus, Linn.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:10:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 10, 3, 3, § 7</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
anathema: <entryFree id="n2460" type="greek" key="a^na^the_ma^1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ănăthēmă</orth>, <itype>ătis</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)na/qhma</foreign>, <sense id="n2460.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">an offering</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a gift</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Prud.</author> Psych. 540</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">in anathema oblivionis,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Vulg.</author> Judith, 16, 23</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>

<entryFree id="n2461" type="greek" key="a^na^the^ma^2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ănăthĕmă</orth>, <itype>ătis</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)na/qema</foreign>, a later form of <foreign lang="greek">a)na/qhma</foreign>, used in mal. part. (eccl. Lat.), pr. <sense id="n2461.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">an offering</hi> not to be redeemed; and of a living thing, to be put to death, doomed; hence, <hi rend="ital">an accursed thing</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a curse.</hi> </sense><sense id="n2461.1" n="I" level="1"> Concr., of things: <cit><quote lang="la">vocavit nomen loci illius Horma, id est anathema,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,004:21:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Num. 21, 3</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,026:1:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Jud. 1, 17</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,005:13:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Deut. 13, 16</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n2461.2" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A curse of excommunication</hi>, <hi rend="ital">anathema</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">anathematis injuria,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2468,001:Ep. 75" default="NO"><author>Aug.</author> Ep. 75</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n2461.3" n="III" level="1"> <usg type="style">Meton.</usg> (like the Heb. <foreign />). </sense><sense id="n2461.4" n="A" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">The person cursed</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">nec inferes quippiam ex idolo in domum tuam, ne fias anathema, sicut et illud est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,005:7:26" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Deut. 7, 26</bibl></cit>. —</sense><sense id="n2461.5" n="B" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">The person excommunicated</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">aliquem anathema dicere,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Tert.</author> adv. Haer. 6</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,006:9:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Rom. 9, 3</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,007:12:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> 1 Cor. 12, 3</bibl>; 16, 22; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,009:1:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Gal. 1, 8</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">1, 9</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
anathematizo: <entryFree id="n2462" type="greek" key="a^na^the^ma^ti_zo"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ănăthĕmătīzo</orth>, <itype>āre</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)naqemati/zw</foreign>.<cb n="ANCE" />  <sense id="n2462.0" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">to anathematize</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to put under the ban</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">aliquem or aliquam rem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2468,001:Ep. 75" default="NO"><author>Aug.</author> Ep. 75</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n2462.1" n="II" level="1"> In gen., <hi rend="ital">to curse</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,023:5:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> 1 Macc. 5, 5</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,002:14:71" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Marc. 14, 71</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n2462.2" n="III" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">To detest</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">aliquid,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Hier.</author> Ep. 75</bibl></cit>.—Form <orth extent="full" lang="la">ănă-thĕmo</orth>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2468,001:Serm. 164" default="NO"><author>Aug.</author> Serm. 164</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2468,001:Temp. 3" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Temp. 3</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2468,001:Ep. 95" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Ep. 95</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
anathemo: <entryFree id="n2463" type="main" key="a^na^the^mo"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ănăthĕmo</orth>, <itype>āre</itype>, v. anathematizo.</entryFree>
anathymiasis: <entryFree id="n2464" type="greek" key="a^na^thy_mi^a_sis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ănăthȳmĭāsis</orth>, <itype>is</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)naqumi/asis</foreign>, <sense id="n2464.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a rising vapor</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Petr.</author> 47</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Theod. Prisc.</author> 2, 2, 1</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
anaticula: <entryFree id="n2465" type="main" key="a^na^ti^cu^la"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ănătĭcŭla</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <lbl>dim.</lbl> <etym>anas</etym>. <sense id="n2465.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A little duck</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a duckling</hi>, * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:5:15:42" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fin. 5, 15, 42</bibl>.— </sense><sense id="n2465.1" n="II" level="1"> In Plaut., a term of endearment, <hi rend="ital">duckie</hi>, * As. 3, 3, 103.</sense></entryFree>
anatinus: <entryFree id="n2466" type="main" key="a^na^ti_nus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ănătīnus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n2466.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">pertaining to the duck</hi>: Utinam fortunam nunc [ego] anatinam uterer, Uti quom exivissem ex aquā, arerem tamen, * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,017:2:6:49" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Rud. 2, 6, 49</bibl>.—Hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">ănătīna</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> (sc. caro), <hi rend="ital">duck-flesh</hi>, <hi rend="ital">duck</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Petr.</author> 56, 3</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
anatocismus: <entryFree id="n2467" type="greek" key="a^na^to^cismus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ănătŏcismus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)natokismo/s</foreign>, <sense id="n2467.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">interest upon interest</hi>, <hi rend="ital">compound interest</hi> (twice in Cic.): <cit><quote lang="la">centesimae cum anatocismo anniversario,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:5:21:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 5, 21, 11</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">5, 21, 12</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Inscr. Orell.</author> 4405</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
anatomia: <entryFree id="n2468" type="greek" key="a^na^to^mi^a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ănătŏmĭa</orth> or <orth extent="full" lang="la">ănătŏmĭca</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, also <orth extent="full" lang="la">ănătŏmĭcē</orth>, <itype>ēs</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">anatomi/a</foreign> or <foreign lang="greek">a)natomikh/</foreign> (sc. <foreign lang="greek">te/xnh</foreign>); <sense id="n2468.0" n="I" level="1"><cit><quote lang="la">in medicine,</quote> <trans><tr>anatomy</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2305,001:Acut. 1:8" default="NO"><author>Cael. Aur.</author> Acut. 1, 8</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Macr.</author> S. 7, 15</bibl>.—Hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">ănătŏmĭcus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> (sc. medicus), <hi rend="ital">an anatomist</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Macr.</author> S. 7, 13</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Amm.</author> 28, 4 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl>; Aug. Civ. Dei, 22, 24.</sense></entryFree>
anatonus: <entryFree id="n2469" type="greek" key="a^na^to^nus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ănătŏnus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)na/tonos</foreign>, <sense id="n2469.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">extending upwards</hi> (opp. catatonus), Capitula, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1056,001:10:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vitr.</author> 10, 15 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></sense></entryFree>
anatresis: <entryFree id="n2470" type="main" key="a^na_^tre_sis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ănā^trēsis</orth>, <itype>is</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)na/trhsis</foreign>, <sense id="n2470.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a boring through</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2305,001:Tard. 2:1" default="NO"><author>Cael. Aur.</author> Tard. 2, 1</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
anaudia: <entryFree id="n2471" type="main" key="a^naudi^a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ănaudĭa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)naudi/a</foreign>, <sense id="n2471.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">loss of speech</hi>, <hi rend="ital">dumbness</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2305,001:Acut. 2:10" default="NO"><author>Cael. Aur.</author> Acut. 2, 10</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
anaurus: <entryFree id="n2472" type="main" key="A^naurus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ănaurus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)/anauros</foreign>, <sense id="n2472.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a river in Thessaly</hi>, <hi rend="ital">that rises near the foot of Pelion</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0917,001:6:370" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Luc.</author> 6, 370</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
anaxagoras: <entryFree id="n2473" type="main" key="A^naxa^go^ras"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ănaxăgŏras</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)anacago/ras</foreign>, <sense id="n2473.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a distinguished Greek philosopher of Clazomenœ</hi>, <hi rend="ital">teacher of Pericles and Euripides</hi>, Lucr 1, 830; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:3:34" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 3, 34</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,039:chapter=11" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Brut. 11</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Ac. 2, 31</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">2, 37 al.</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:12:2:22" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 12, 2, 22</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1038,001:5:10" default="NO"><author>Val. Max.</author> 5, 10</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:15:20 al" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 15, 20 al.</bibl></sense></entryFree>
anaxarchus: <entryFree id="n2474" type="main" key="A^naxarchus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ănaxarchus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)ana/carxos</foreign>, <sense id="n2474.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a philosopher of Abdera</hi>, <hi rend="ital">and follower of the philosophy of Democritus</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1038,001:3:3" default="NO"><author>Val. Max.</author> 3, 3</bibl>, n. 4; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,010:573" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> Ib. 573</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
anaxarete: <entryFree id="n2475" type="main" key="A^naxa^re^te_"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ănaxărĕtē</orth>, <itype>ēs</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, <sense id="n2475.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a rich and beautiful maiden of Cyprus</hi>, <hi rend="ital">who</hi>, <hi rend="ital">disdaining the love of Iphis</hi>, <hi rend="ital">was changed to a stone</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:14:699" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 14, 699</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
anaximander: <entryFree id="n2476" type="main" key="A^naxi^mander"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ănaxĭmander</orth>, <itype>dri</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)anaci/mandros</foreign>, <sense id="n2476.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a distinguished Ionian philosopher of Miletus</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:1:50" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Div. 1, 50</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:1:10 al" default="NO"><author>id.</author> N. D. 1, 10 al.</bibl></sense></entryFree>
ancaesa: <entryFree id="n2477" type="gloss" key="ancaesa"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ancaesa</orth>, <itype>ōrum</itype>, <gen>n.</gen> <etym>am-caedo</etym>, an old word for caelata: vasa sic dicta, quod circumcaedendo talia fiunt, Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=20" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 20</bibl> Müll.</entryFree>
ancaeus: <entryFree id="n2478" type="main" key="Ancaeus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ancaeus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)agkai=os</foreign>, <sense id="n2478.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">an Arcadian</hi>, <hi rend="ital">slain by the Calydonian bcar</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:8:315" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 8, 315</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">8, 401</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">8, 519</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
ancala: <entryFree id="n2479" type="greek" key="anca^la"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ancăla</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, or <orth extent="full" lang="la">-ē</orth>, <itype>ēs</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)gka/lh</foreign> (the bent arm), <sense id="n2479.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the bend of the knee</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the knee</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2305,001:Tard. 5:1" default="NO"><author>Cael. Aur.</author> Tard. 5, 1</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
ancalites: <entryFree id="n2480" type="main" key="Anca^li^tes"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ancălĭtes</orth>, <itype>um</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n2480.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a people in Britain</hi>, otherwise unknown, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:5:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 5, 21</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
anceps: <entryFree id="n2481" type="main" key="anceps"><orth extent="full" lang="la">anceps</orth> (once ancipes, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,017:4:4:114" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Rud. 4, 4, 114</bibl>; cf. Charis, pp. 67 and 96 P.; <bibl default="NO"><author>Prisc.</author> p. 754</bibl> P.; with this form cf. procapis, Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=225" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 225</bibl> Müll., and Corss. Ausspr. II. pp. 398, 591; <sense id="n2481.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">abl. sing.</hi> always ancipiti), <itype>cĭpĭtis</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>an-caput; cf. Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=19" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 19</bibl> Müll.</etym>. </sense><sense id="n2481.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">that has two heads</hi>, <hi rend="ital">twoheaded</hi> (cf.: biceps, praeceps, etc.; <cit><quote lang="la">so only in the poets): Janus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:14:334" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 14, 334</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,007:1:95" default="NO"><author>id.</author> F. 1, 95</bibl> (cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">Janus bifrons,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:7:180" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 7, 180</bibl></cit>). —Hence also of a mountain which has two summits, <hi rend="ital">two-peaked</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">acumen,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:12:337" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 12, 337</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n2481.2" n="II" level="1"> In gen. </sense><sense id="n2481.3" n="A. 1." level="1"> Of an object whose qualities have significance in two respects, <hi rend="ital">double</hi>, <hi rend="ital">that extends on two opposite sides</hi> (while duplex is an object that exists in separate forms, twice. Thus anceps sententia is <hi rend="ital">an opinion which wavers</hi>, <hi rend="ital">fluctuates between two decisions</hi>, while duplex sententia is a twofold opinion): <cit><quote lang="la">Post altrinsecus ancipes securiculast,</quote> <trans><tr>the axe cuts on two sides</tr>, <tr>is two-edged</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,017:4:4:114" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Rud. 4, 4, 114</bibl></cit>; so, ferrum, Lucil. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> p. 245, 17</bibl>, and <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:6:168" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 6, 168</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">securis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:8:397 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 8, 397 al.</bibl></cit>—Also, <usg type="style">poet.</usg>, <cb n="ANCI" /> of the contrast between great heat and cold: Ancipiti quoniam mucroni utrimque notantur, <hi rend="ital">since things are marked by double point</hi>, i. e. one at one, another at the other end, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:2:520" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 2, 520</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">bestiae quasi ancipites in utrāque sede viventes,</quote> <trans><tr>amphibious animals</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:1:37" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 1, 37</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">so in the histt. freq. of an attack, a contest, etc., on two different sides,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:7:76" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 7, 76</bibl></cit>: ita ancipiti proelio diu atque acriter pugnatum est, <hi rend="ital">double</hi>, because contending with enemies both in front and in the rear, <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 26</bibl> Herz.; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:3:63" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> B. C. 3, 63</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,002:3:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Them. 3, 3</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">periculum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 38:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 38, 5</bibl></cit>: ancipitem pugnam hostibus facere, <hi rend="ital">double</hi>, as given by horse and foot, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:6:35" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 6, 35</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ancipiti metu et ab cive et ab hoste,</quote> <trans><tr>twofold</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:2:24" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 2, 24</bibl></cit>; so, <cit><quote lang="la">anceps terror,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:34:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 34, 21</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,001:26" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> Agr. 26</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">tumultus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:32:30" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 32, 30</bibl></cit>: tela, <hi rend="ital">shot</hi> or <hi rend="ital">hurled from both sides</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:37:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 37, 11</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ancipitia munimenta,</quote> <trans><tr>on two sides</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:5:1 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 5, 1 al.</bibl></cit>—</sense><sense id="n2481.4" n="2" level="3"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">twofold</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">propter ancipitem faciendi dicendique sapientiam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:3:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 3, 16</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ancipites viae rationesque et pro omnibus et contra omnia disputandi,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 3, 36</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">adferre ancipitem curam cogitandi,</quote> <trans><tr>a twofold care of thought</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:1:3:9" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Off. 1, 3, 9</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:2:40" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 2, 40</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">jus anceps,</quote> <trans><tr>the uncertainties of law</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:2:5:34 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 2, 5, 34 al.</bibl></cit>—</sense><sense id="n2481.5" n="B" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">Wavering</hi>, <hi rend="ital">doubtful</hi>, <hi rend="ital">uncertain</hi>, <hi rend="ital">unfixed</hi>, <hi rend="ital">undecided</hi> (the prevalent signif. in Cic.): <cit><quote lang="la">anceps fatorum via,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Somn. Scip. 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">incertus exitus et anceps fortuna belli,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,032:chapter=5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Marcell. 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">anceps proelii fortuna,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:3:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 3, 18</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">oraculum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:9:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 9, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">proelium,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:2:62" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 2, 62</bibl></cit>, and <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:3:22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 3, 22</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">so esp. freq.: ancipiti Marte pugnare,</quote> <trans><tr>to contend without deciding the contest</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:7:29" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 7, 29</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:21:1 al" default="NO" valid="yes">21, 1 al.</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">causa anceps,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:2:44" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 2, 44</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">genus causarum anceps,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,036:1:15:20" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Inv. 1, 15, 20</bibl></cit> (cf.: genus causarum dubium, Auct. ad <bibl default="NO"><author>Her.</author> 1, 3</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">dubium vel anceps,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:4:1:10" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 4, 1, 10</bibl></cit>): <cit><quote lang="la">fides,</quote> <trans><tr>uncertain</tr>, <tr>wavering</tr>, <tr>fidelity</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:3:8" default="NO"><author>Curt.</author> 3, 8</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">so also, ancipites animi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0917,001:9:46" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Luc.</author> 9, 46</bibl></cit>.—Also ellipt.: Lucanus an Apulus, anceps, <hi rend="ital">doubtful whether</hi>, etc., * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:2:1:34" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 2, 1, 34</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n2481.6" n="C" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">Dangerous</hi>, <hi rend="ital">hazardous</hi>, <hi rend="ital">perilous</hi>, <hi rend="ital">critical</hi> (post-Aug.; esp. freq. in Tac.; <cit><quote lang="la">never in Cic.): viae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:14:438" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 14, 438</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">loca,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,014:7:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Dat. 7, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">dubiā et interdum ancipiti fortunā,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1044,001:2:79" default="NO"><author>Vell.</author> 2, 79</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">anceps periculum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:4:59" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 4, 59</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ancipites morbi corporis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:7:149" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 7, 45, 46, § 149</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cujus (Antonii) operā ex ancipiti morbo convaluerat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=aug.:59" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Aug. 59</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Ideo et purgationibus (labruscum) ancipitem putant,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:23:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 23, 1, 14, § 20</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">vox pro re publicā honesta, ipsi anceps,</quote> <trans><tr>pernicious</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:1:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 1, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">adulatio anceps si nulla et ubi nimia est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:4:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> A. 4, 17</bibl></cit>.—So <hi rend="ital">subst.</hi>, <hi rend="ital">danger</hi>, <hi rend="ital">hazard</hi>, <hi rend="ital">peril</hi>, = periculum, discrimen: <cit><quote lang="la">dubiā suorum re in anceps tractus vim legionum implorabat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:4:73" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 4, 73</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">seu nihil militi seu omnia concederentur, in ancipiti res publica,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 36</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">scelus inter ancipitia probatum,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 11, 26</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">14, 22: facilius inter ancipitia clarescunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,002:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> G. 14</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nova ambigua ancipitia malebat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:2:86" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> H. 2, 86</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">inter ancipitia deterrimum est media sequi,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 3, 40</bibl></cit>.!*? <hi rend="ital">Comp.</hi>, <hi rend="ital">sup.</hi>, and <pos>adv.</pos> not used.</sense></entryFree>
ancharius: <entryFree id="n2482" type="main" key="Ancha_ri^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Anchārĭus</orth>, <itype>ii</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n2482.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a Roman family name</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,022:chapter=53" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Sest. 53</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,027:chapter=38" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Pis. 38</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ad Div. 13, 40</bibl>.—Hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">Anchārĭānus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, <hi rend="ital">pertaining thereto</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Quint. 4, 1, 74</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
anchises: <entryFree id="n2483" type="main" key="Anchi_ses"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Anchīses</orth> (old orthog. <orth extent="full" lang="la">Agchīses</orth>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:L. L. Fragm. p. 264" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> L. L. Fragm. p. 264</bibl> Müll.; <case>nom.</case> Anchisa, Naev. B. Pun. Fragm. ap. Prob. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:1:5:61" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 1, 5, 61</bibl>; <case>acc.</case> Ancisem, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0400,001:Trag. Rel. p. 220" default="NO"><author>Att.</author> Trag. Rel. p. 220</bibl> Rib.; <case>abl.</case> Anchisā, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:5:244" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 5, 244</bibl>), <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)agxi/shs</foreign>. <sense id="n2483.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Son of Capys</hi>, <hi rend="ital">father of Æneas</hi>, <hi rend="ital">who bore him forth from burning Troy upon his shoulders</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0043,001:1:30" default="NO"><author>Enn.</author> Ann. 1, 30</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:1:617" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 1, 617</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">3, 710</bibl> sq.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:9:425" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 9, 425</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">13, 640</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">13, 680 al.</bibl>—Hence, </sense><sense id="n2483.1" n="II" level="1"> Derivv. </sense><sense id="n2483.2" n="A" level="2"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Anchīsēus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, <hi rend="ital">of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">belonging to Anchises</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">tumulus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:5:761" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 5, 761</bibl></cit>; and </sense><sense id="n2483.3" n="B" level="2"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Anchīsĭădes</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <hi rend="ital">patr.</hi>, <hi rend="ital">son of Anchises</hi>, i. e. <hi rend="ital">Æneas</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:6:348" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 6, 348</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
anchora: <entryFree id="n2484" type="main" key="ancho^ra"><orth extent="full" lang="la">anchŏra</orth> and <orth extent="full" lang="la">anchŏrālis</orth>, v. ancora, etc.</entryFree>
anchusa: <entryFree id="n2485" type="greek" key="anchu_sa"><orth extent="full" lang="la">anchūsa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)/gxousa</foreign>, <sense id="n2485.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a plant used as a cosmetic</hi>, <hi rend="ital">ox-tongue</hi>: Anchusa tinctoria, Linn.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:22:48" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 22, 20, 23, § 48</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
ancile: <entryFree id="n2486" type="main" key="anci_le"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ancīle</orth> (also <orth extent="full" lang="la">ancŭle</orth> after <foreign lang="greek">a)gku/lion</foreign> in Plut. Num.), <itype>is</itype>, <gen>n.</gen> (<sense id="n2486.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">gen. plur.</hi> ancilium, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:1:89" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 1, 89</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">but anciliorum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:3:5:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 3, 5, 10</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>Consent.</author> p. 1898</bibl> P.) [prob. from <foreign lang="greek">a)gku/los</foreign>, crooked, curved; <cit><quote lang="la">v. ango],</quote> <trans><tr>a small oval shield</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:7:188" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 7, 188</bibl></cit> Serv.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0917,001:9:480" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Luc.</author> 9, 480</bibl>; but specif. <hi rend="ital">the shield that was said to have fallen from heaven in the reign of Numa</hi> <pb n="117" /> <cb n="ANCO" /> (hence, caelestia arma, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:1:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 1, 20</bibl>), <hi rend="ital">and on the preservation of which the prosperity of Rome was declared to depend;</hi> whereupon Numa caused eleven others exactly like it to be made by the artist Mamurius Veturius. so that if the genuine one was lost, the fact could not be known. These shields were carefully preserved by the Salian priests in the temple of Mars, and every year in March carried about in solemn procession (ancilia movere), and then returned to their place (ancilia condere), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,007:3:377" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> F. 3, 377</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:1:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 1, 20</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:8:664" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 8, 664</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:1:89" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 1, 89</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=otho:8" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Oth. 8</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Inscr. Orell.</author> 2244</bibl>; v. Smith, Dict. Antiq.!*? <hi rend="ital">Adj.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">clipeis ancilibus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:2:126" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 2, 126</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">arma ancilia,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1038,001:1:1:9" default="NO"><author>Val. Max.</author> 1, 1, 9</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
ancilla: <entryFree id="n2487" type="main" key="ancilla"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ancilla</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <lbl>dim.</lbl> <etym>ancula</etym>, <sense id="n2487.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a maidservant</hi>, <hi rend="ital">handmaid</hi>, <hi rend="ital">female slave</hi> (com. used as <hi rend="ital">fem.</hi> of servus, instead of serva). </sense><sense id="n2487.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>, Liv. Andron. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> p. 153</bibl> (Trag. Rel. p. 3 Rib.): <hi rend="ital">Am.</hi> Quis me tenet? <hi rend="ital">Br.</hi> Tua Bromia ancilla, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,001:5:1:25" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Am. 5, 1, 25</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ecqua ancilla est illi?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,012:3:1:199" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Mil. 3, 1, 199</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Servos, ancillas amove, atque audin?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,019:3:3:70" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Trin. 3, 3, 70</bibl></cit> et saep.: <cit><quote lang="la">ancilla aere empta,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,004:3:2:26" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Phorm. 3, 2, 26</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:3:1:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> And. 3, 1, 3</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">5, 1, 19</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:1:1:78" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Heaut. 1, 1, 78</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">5, 1, 20</bibl> et saep.: <cit><quote lang="la">ancillarum beneficio emitti,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,021:chapter=42" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Har. Resp. 42</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ducebat ancillarum greges,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,031:chapter=55" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Mil. 55</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">hunc servi ancillaeque amant,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:3:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 2, 3, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum ancillarum puerorumque comitatu,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,031:10 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Mil. 10 al.</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">occultat se in tugurio mulieris ancillae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 12:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 12, 5</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:2:4:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 2, 4, 1</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:1:2:63" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> S. 1, 2, 63</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">1, 2, 117</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">2, 3, 215</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Ep. 1, 18, 72</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">nec (liberi) ancillis aut nutricibus delegantur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,002:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> G. 20</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Or. 29</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ancilla dominā validior,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:14:63" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> A. 14, 63</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n2487.2" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">terrā usus mortalium semper ancillā,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:2:155" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 2, 63, 63, § 155</bibl></cit>.—As a term of reproach, of one servilely devoted to any thing: <cit><quote lang="la">Fufidius ancilla turpis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:H. 1:15, p. 218" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> H. 1, 15, p. 218</bibl></cit> Gerl.</sense></entryFree>
ancillariolus: <entryFree id="n2488" type="main" key="ancilla_ri^o^lus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ancillārĭŏlus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>ancilla</etym>, <sense id="n2488.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a lover of maid-servants</hi> (very rare), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:12:58" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 12, 58</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Ben. 1:9" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Ben. 1, 9</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
ancillaris: <entryFree id="n2489" type="main" key="ancilla_ris"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ancillāris</orth>, <itype>e</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n2489.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">relating to maid - servants.</hi> </sense><sense id="n2489.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: artificium, <hi rend="ital">the service of handmaid</hi>, * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:5:20:58" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 5, 20, 58</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ancillaris vestis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:47:10:15:section=15" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 47, 10, 15, § 15</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n2489.2" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">adulatio ancillaris,</quote> <trans><tr>servile flattery</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>Amm.</author> 26, 6</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
ancillatus: <entryFree id="n2490" type="hapax" key="ancilla_tus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ancillātus</orth>, <itype>ūs</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>ancillor</etym>, <sense id="n2490.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the service of a female slave</hi>, or in gen. <hi rend="ital">of a slave</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Arn.</author> 7, p. 221</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
ancillor: <entryFree id="n2491" type="main" key="ancillor"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ancillor</orth>, <itype>ātus, 1</itype>, <pos>v. dep.</pos> and <gen>n.</gen> <etym>ancilla</etym>, pr., <sense id="n2491.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to serve as handmaid;</hi> hence, in gen., <hi rend="ital">to serve</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to attend upon</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to be subservient to</hi>, etc. (only ante-class. and post-Aug.): invita ancillans, Att. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> p. 72, 3</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">uxoribus ancillantur, Titin. ib.: aestus (maris) ancillantes siderum avido trahenti etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:2:213" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 2, 97, 99, § 213</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cetera membra ancillari et subservire capiti,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> Dogm. Plat. 1, p. 9, 17</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
ancillula: <entryFree id="n2492" type="main" key="ancillu^la"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ancillŭla</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <sense id="n2492.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">doub. dim.</hi> [id.], <hi rend="ital">a little serving-maid</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a young female slave.</hi> </sense><sense id="n2492.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,017:prol. 74" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Rud. prol. 74</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:2:3:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Heaut. 2, 3, 11</bibl>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,003:1:2:86" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Eun. 1, 2, 86</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,004:5:5:10 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Phorm. 5, 5, 10 al.</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">nec servus nec ancillula, etc.,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> R. Am. 639 al.</bibl></cit>—</sense><sense id="n2492.2" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">juris scientiam eloquentiae tamquam ancillulam pedissequamque adjunxisti,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:1:55" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 1, 55 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">praesto esse virtutes ut ancillulas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:2:21:69" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Fin. 2, 21, 69</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
ancipes: <entryFree id="n2493" type="main" key="anci^pes"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ancĭpes</orth>, v. anceps.<sense id="n2493.0" n="1" level="3"> * <orth extent="full" lang="la">ancīsus</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">amc-</orth>), <itype>a, um</itype> <etym>qs. <hi rend="ital">part.</hi> of ancido</etym>, <hi rend="ital">cut around</hi> or <hi rend="ital">away</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">omnia ancisa recenti Volnere,</quote> <trans><tr>every part cut with fresh wounds</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:3:660" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 3, 660</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
ancisus: <entryFree id="n2494" type="spur" key="anci_sus" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ancīsus</orth>, <itype>ūs</itype>, a false read. for ambecisus, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:L. L. 7:section=43" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> L. L. 7, § 43</bibl> Müll.; v. ambecisus.</entryFree>
anclabris: <entryFree id="n2495" type="gloss" key="ancla^bris"><orth extent="full" lang="la">anclăbris</orth>, <itype>is</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>anclo</etym>, <sense id="n2495.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a sacrificial table.</hi> The vessels upon it were called anclabria: anclabris: mensa ministeriis divinis aptata. Vasa quoque in eā, quibus sacerdotes utuntur, anclabria appellantur, Paul. ex Fest. pp. 11. 51 Müll.</sense></entryFree>
anclo: <entryFree id="n2496" type="main" key="anclo"><orth extent="full" lang="la">anclo</orth> or <orth extent="full" lang="la">ancŭlo</orth>, <itype>āre</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos> <etym>anculus</etym>, <sense id="n2496.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to serve with</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to bring</hi> something <hi rend="ital">as servant</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to have the care of</hi> (only in Liv. Andron.): antiqui anculare dicebant pro ministrare, Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=20" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 20</bibl> Müll.: carnis vinumque, quod libabant, anclabatur, ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Prisc.</author> p. 684</bibl> P.: florem anculabant, ap. Fest. l. c. (Trag. Rel. p. 4 Rib.).</sense></entryFree>
ancon: <entryFree id="n2497" type="greek" key="anco_n1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ancōn</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>v. ango</etym>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)gkw/n</foreign> (the bend of the arm), t. t., for the pure Lat. cubitum. <sense id="n2497.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">The arm of a workman's square</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1056,001:3:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vitr.</author> 3, 3 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1056,001:8:6" default="NO" valid="yes">8, 6</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n2497.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A stone in</hi> <cb n="ANDA" /> <hi rend="ital">a wall</hi>, <hi rend="ital">which projects above more than below</hi>, <hi rend="ital">and supports something; a console</hi> or <hi rend="ital">volute</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1056,001:4:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vitr.</author> 4, 6</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n2497.2" n="III" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">The knobbed bars of a hydraulic engine</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1056,001:10:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vitr.</author> 10, 13</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n2497.3" n="IV" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Forked poles for spreading nets</hi> (pure Lat., ames, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,003:2:33" default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Epod. 2, 33</bibl>), <bibl default="NO"><author>Grat.</author> Cyn. 87</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n2497.4" n="V" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">The arm of a chair</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2305,001:Tard. 2:1" default="NO"><author>Cael. Aur.</author> Tard. 2, 1</bibl>.— </sense><sense id="n2497.5" n="VI" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A kind of drinking-vessel in an alehouse</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:33:7:13" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 33, 7, 13</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>

<entryFree id="n2498" type="main" key="Anco_n2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ancōn</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>v. ango</etym>, <sense id="n2498.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a headland and bay</hi>, as the name implies, <hi rend="ital">on the coast of Pontus</hi>, <hi rend="ital">east of Amisus</hi>, now <hi rend="ital">Derbend Bournow</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1035,001:4:600" default="NO"><author>Val. Fl.</author> 4, 600</bibl>; cf. Apoll. Rhod. 2, 369.</sense></entryFree>

<entryFree id="n2499" type="main" key="Anco_n3" n="3"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ancōn</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, or <orth extent="full" lang="la">Ancōna</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>v. ango</etym>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)agkw/n</foreign>, <sense id="n2499.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">an ancient seaport town in the north of Picenum</hi>, <hi rend="ital">situated on a promontory forming a remarkable curve</hi> or <hi rend="ital">elbow</hi>, as the name implies, <hi rend="ital">founded by the Syracusans</hi>, <hi rend="ital">still called Ancona;</hi> form <orth extent="full" lang="la">Ancōna</orth>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:12:9:23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Phil. 12, 9, 23</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:16:12:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 16, 12, 2</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:1:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. C. 1, 11</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:2:182" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 2, 72, 74, § 182</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:3:111" default="NO" valid="yes">3, 13, 18, § 111</bibl> sq. al.—Form <orth extent="full" lang="la">Ancōn</orth>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0929,001:2:4:5" default="NO"><author>Mel.</author> 2, 4, 5</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0472,001:36:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cat.</author> 36, 13</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:8:438" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 8, 438</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:4:40 al" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 4, 40 al.</bibl>; and in a pun: Cingulum nos tenemus; <cit><quote lang="la">Anconem amisimus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:7:11:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 7, 11, 1</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
ancora: <entryFree id="n2500" type="greek" key="anco^ra"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ancŏra</orth>, <itype>ae</itype> (not <orth extent="full" lang="la">anchŏra</orth>), <gen>f.</gen> <etym>v. ango</etym>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)/gku=ra</foreign>, <sense id="n2500.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">an anchor.</hi> </sense><sense id="n2500.1" n="I. A." level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">Ancora fundabat naves,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:6:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 6, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">jacere,</quote> <trans><tr>to cast anchor</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:4:28" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 4, 28</bibl></cit>; so, <cit><quote lang="la">mittere,</quote> <trans><tr>to let go</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,005:27:29" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Act. 27, 29</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">extendere,</quote> <trans><tr>to put out</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> ib. 27, 30</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">naves deligare ad ancoras,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:4:29" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 4, 29</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">navem tenere in ancoris,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,002:8:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Them. 8, 7</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">consistere ad ancoram,</quote> <trans><tr>to lie at anchor</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:3:102" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. C. 3, 102</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">naves in ancoris constiterunt,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 3, 28</bibl></cit> et saep.: <cit><quote lang="la">solvere,</quote> <trans><tr>to weigh anchor</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:1:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 1, 13</bibl></cit>; so, <cit><quote lang="la">tollere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:1:31" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. C. 1, 31</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,005:27:40" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Act. 27, 40</bibl>; also, <cit><quote lang="la">in gen.,</quote> <trans><tr>to depart</tr>, <tr>go away</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 3:17:1" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 3, 17, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">vellere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:22:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 22, 19</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">praecidere,</quote> <trans><tr>to cut the cables</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:5:34 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 5, 34 al.</bibl></cit>—</sense><sense id="n2500.2" n="B" level="2"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>, as a symbol of security, <hi rend="ital">refuge</hi>, <hi rend="ital">hope</hi>, <hi rend="ital">support</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ancora jam nostram non tenet ulla ratem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,008:5:2:42" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> Tr. 5, 2, 42</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ultima fessis ancora,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:7:24" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 7, 24</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">spem, quam sicut ancoram habemus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,019:6:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Heb. 6, 10</bibl></cit>.— </sense><sense id="n2500.3" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">an iron in the form of an anchor</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Pall.</author> 1, 40, 5</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
ancorago: <entryFree id="n2501" type="hapax" key="anco^ra_go"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ancŏrāgo</orth>, <itype>ĭnis</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>prob. ancora</etym>, <sense id="n2501.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a fish in the Rhine</hi>, now unknown, <bibl default="NO"><author>Cassiod.</author> Ep. 12, 4</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
